Headline: Barron's(6/18) The Rise Of The House Of Lehman: Chapter II
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   Mythology often shapes, and reshapes, Wall Street's perceptions. Companies and chief executives become symbols and caricatures so investors can more easily relate to them. Lehman Brothers, the story went, was too small and narrowly focused to survive once American Express dumped it in 1994. But the bank and its head, Richard S. Fuld Jr., instead came to embody Wall Street pluck by defying the consensus and outlasting many bigger rivals with broader business lines.   Once again, Lehman (ticker: LEH) is going up against perceptions. It's battling to join the likes of Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS) as an elite international investment bank. Yet the firm is having a tough time getting its due as it recalibrates its strategy to leverage its core fixed-income expertise and increase international revenue.   Strong second-quarter earnings released last week helped its case, but Lehman is still perceived as a plodding bond house with a potentially damaging exposure to risky mortgages. In many ways that's a myth, though bonds and their many derivations do dominate Lehman's revenues. The fact is that it has made substantial strides in equities and investment banking here and abroad. In the second quarter, net revenue from equity capital markets nearly doubled over the year-ago period to $1.7 billion, helping offset weakness in bond trading.   Lehman's stock, however, lags behind its more heralded, faster-growing peers. After leading the brokerage sector for several years, the shares, which have risen just 1% this year, are up 29% over the past 12 months -- well behind Goldman's 63% gain and Morgan Stanley's 61% rise. Its book value is also substantially less.   "There is a level of questioning and malaise about Lehman, not because of cracks in the armor, but because you have to ask questions when a company is underperforming the peer group after outperforming for some time," says brokerage analyst Guy Moszkowski of Merrill Lynch.   But for investors comfortable going against the crowd -- or at least advancing slightly ahead of it, these questions offer an opportunity to buy the weak stock of a firm with a stable franchise that could ultimately join the ranks of the top investment banks. In fact, a case could be made that buying Lehman shares is like owning a position in a smaller, more risk-averse Goldman Sachs. Applying Morgan Stanley's 2.57 multiple of price to book value would lift Lehman shares by about 24% to 99; at Goldman's 2.93, they'd jump 38%. Lehman's book value, at $37.15 at the end of the second quarter, has gained 124% over the past five years.     Fuld knows his firm is misunderstood. "Whether the world catches on today or tomorrow, I've got plenty of time for that. I like that we're not fully appreciated," he recently told Barron's. "We have so much to do here as we build out Europe and India and China."   Fuld makes no apologies for moving slower than some competitors to expand overseas. Ditto for not going after as many private-equity deals. And ditto for curtailing the firm's risk-taking in 2006 when he found some "disquieting" factors at work in the markets.   Now Lehman seems intent on taking on more trading and deal risk, and using its balance sheet to commit more capital -- without losing sight of risk scenarios. If bankers sell themes and ideas, traders assess risk. And Fuld is a former bond trader. But even critics concede he also has a great record of delivering on his plan.   Fuld says a lot of bad deals have been made to look good because of easy credit. When Lehman finds a good deal, he says, it commits capital as it has in participating in the $32 billion buyout bid for utility TXU (TXU). Want more proof? Lehman bought Eagle Energy Partners, which provides it with a global energy and commodities platform. Still more? It made a 20% investment in D.E. Shaw, the world's fourth largest hedge fund, and has signed on to the proposed $15.2 billion buyout of Archstone-Smith, a real-estate investment trust, with Tishman Speyer and Bank of America.   Lehman's investment bankers are advising on some of the world's biggest mergers and acquisitions, including those for ABN-AMRO, Endesa and Alcoa.   "Our goal," Fuld says, "is to be a provider of capital. I don't want to go to auction on assets. We're doing partnerships with clients and getting assets at reasonable levels."   Fuld's distinction is important. Many investment banks today, especially Goldman, are chided for competing with their customers rather than helping them make money. He's following a different route.     The complaint about Lehman is that its balance sheet isn't big enough to do many big deals. At about $600 billion, it isn't nearly as large as Goldman's $912 billion or Morgan Stanley's more than $1.2 trillion. Citigroup's (C) balance sheet is about $2 trillion, while JPMorgan's (JPM) is roughly $1.4 trillion.   To be sure, Lehman does not want to be all things to all clients, and $600 billion still offers the flexibility to do back flips to win selected deals. But building an investment-banking franchise is more challenging if a bank is not recognized as willing to make major financial commitments readily.   This is a significant issue when relationships are effectively being auctioned: Lehman's risk appetite will set the pace of its advance up the league tables. In 2006, the firm ranked ninth in global leveraged buyouts based on value and market share and seventh in global completed M&A. Goldman and the other firms with larger balance sheets dominate these rankings.   "Lehman's made huge strides relative to the Lehman franchise," says Lauren Smith, a Keefe, Bruyette & Woods analyst. "But they haven't really broken into the top tier and gone toe-to-toe with the global bulge-bracket competitors."   Lehman's response appears to have been creating a senior position tasked with managing strategic partnerships, principal investing and risk. David Goldfarb, the firm's former financial and administrative chief, now supervises all principal investments, mergers and acquisitions and strategic joint ventures. He also oversees the internal investment businesses of global trading and principal strategies.   "Risk appetite is something they have to come to terms with," says Merrill analyst Moszkowski. "They've opened up the risk book a little and they've closed some of that gap relative to others. They're doing it judiciously and effectively and it is starting to make a difference."   Lehman, like other investment banks, trades at 10 times forward earnings. This influences the revenue multiples it pays for deals because anything above 10 times earnings is not immediately accretive. "We see tons of opportunity, and in all fairness we're trying to pick the right one," Fuld says. "We're buying at lower levels when some guys think they should go at 25 to 30 times earnings. When we buy earnings or capabilities, we want to create shareholder value."   Paradoxically, price-to-earnings ratios are not particularly relevant in assessing brokerage firms' shares. The ratio is chronically low in reflection of the difficulty in forecasting volatile earnings. The more relevant measure is price to book value, where it trails Goldman and Morgan (see chart).   Lehman shares' relative weakness suggests something's amiss. Sure, Lehman lacks scale in high-margin businesses like proprietary trading, which has a cross-cycle pre-tax margin of 29% to 44%, or prime brokerage, which offers pre-tax margins of 20% to 53%, but it is still increasing revenue and earnings -- just not as much as competitors.   Lehman on Tuesday reported a 27% gain in second-quarter net income on the strength of equities trading, investment banking and international operations. But analyst questions on the subsequent conference call focused on subprime mortgages --  which Lehman has said are about 3% of revenues. It seems analysts may be having a hard time seeing the emerging story line at Lehman because they're so concerned about mortgage risk, which did hurt earnings at Bear Stearns and Goldman. Lehman's earnings beat consensus estimates by 18%, suggesting the analysts are too cautious.   As a mile marker, Lehman's second-quarter earnings demonstrate that the firm is progressing toward its goal of diversifying revenues by asset class and geography. Formerly lethargic investment-banking revenues increased by 55%, and non-U.S. revenues reached 48% of the firm's total. Equity trading set a record. Fixed income, the traditional driver of Lehman's growth, fell 14% from the previous year as U.S. subprime- mortgage originations were flat.   Until recently, Lehman's rivals were doing better, and growing faster. But on Thursday Goldman's stock fell 3% when it reported a 1% gain in quarterly profits following a sharp drop in once-strong trading revenues. Bear's second-quarter result fell short of a reduced earnings-consensus estimate, reflecting ongoing mortgage woes. Lehman, in its fourth straight year of record revenue, also has a higher return on equity and pretax margin than Bear, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley.   Lehman's risk levels aren't as high as Goldman's or Morgan Stanley's. Value at risk, a measure of a firm's market risk, was $78 million in the second quarter at Lehman, well below Goldman's $133 million and, in the first quarter, Morgan Stanley's $90 million.The volatility of Lehman's quarterly earnings is almost half that of the typical brokerage firm (see chart). Lehman thus offers investors a way to profit steadily from the rise of global capital markets without assuming high proprietary trading risk or the possible downside to aggressive deal making.     For the first time in Lehman's history, the head of fixed income -- responsible for about 49% of the firm's annual revenue -- is based outside the U.S. Roger Nagioff, a former co-head of global equities, is in London. Nagioff's appointment is a clear sign of Lehman's intention to internationalize its fixed-income machine across Europe, Asia and the Middle East, while also expanding investment banking and equity trading.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: TNK-BP Edges Toward Accord With Gazprom -FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Anglo-Russian oil venture TNK-BP (TNBP.RS) is inching toward an agreement with Gazprom (GSPBEX.RS) over the state-controlled gas giant taking a stake in its Kovykta gas field, the Financial Times reported Saturday, quoting two people close to the company.   The move comes as Russia again delayed a decision on whether to revoke TNK-BP's license.   The newspaper quoted one person close to TNK-BP as having said negotiations between TNK-BP, BP (BP.LN) and Gazprom were moving ahead after a "number of discussions" during a major investment forum in St Petersburg that was attended by BP's new chief executive Tony Hayward last weekend.   Russia had first been due to make a decision two weeks ago on revoking TNK-BP's license to develop its vast east Siberian Kovykta gas field over production violations. But a decision was delayed for up to two weeks amid warnings that withdrawing the license could further damage Russia's investment climate, the FT reported.   According to the FT, Senior Gazprom officials have acknowledged the gas company was in discussions over entering the project.   The newspaper said that BP is believed to be offering Gazprom participation in several of its international projects as part of a broader deal to resolve the standoff.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 07:57 ET (11:57 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Barron's Roundtable: Room To Run -6-
Story: A: Waiting. The one stock that continues to interest me now is Citigroup [C]. Big-caps are coming back into favor, but this one hasn't been smiled upon. It didn't do that badly last year, but is down 3% year to date. Citi has started to pay attention to fundamentals, such as non-interest expense relative to revenue. In the most recent quarter, revenue was up 15% and non-interest expenses were up 10%, and the the company announced it was laying off 17,000 people.   Citi is a genuine 10%-12% grower, in my view, with a 4% yield, and it is selling for just a tick over 10 times next year's earnings. That's a steal. The market is going to get around to it, and you'll see more attention-getting numbers. Citi could get back to a market multiple. If it earns $5.90 a share in 2009, at a 13x multiple that gives you 39% appreciation, plus the yield.     Q: What is behind hedge-fund manager Eddie Lambert's investment in Citi?   A: He might be looking at some of the same fundamentals, though I don't know him or his views. A number of people have talked about breaking up the company, which is not a good idea. Citi has economies of scale that give you the kind of growth I'm predicting, particularly in emerging markets. I'd like to keep that under my wing. The CEO, Chuck Prince, finally has turned his attention and his company's attention to making sure non-interest expenses go up less than revenue. He has done a reasonably good job and deserves more time and attention paid to his results.     Thank you, John.   MARC FABER     Q: What was the U.S. market's recent pullback telling us?   Faber: The economies of the rest of the world have been very strong in the first five months of 2007, whereas U.S. consumption has slowed. If GDP and the rate of inflation were measured properly, we would see the U.S. already has reached the no-growth stage, but with some inflation -- in other words, stagflation. The housing downturn has hurt consumers, and retail sales have been disappointing. If nominal GDP is 6% and inflation is 2%, you get 4% real growth. But if inflation is 5%, you get only 1% growth. In other ways, too, the world has a dual economy. A lot of money flows into the pockets of affluent people, as evidenced by the continued rise of London property prices, art prices at auctions, fine wines and so forth. The economy of the middle class and the workers is not doing particularly well.     Q: What does this mean for the stock markets of the world?   A: The U.S. stock market, like all other asset markets, is in cuckoo land. We have bubbles everywhere, which hasn't happened before. The 19th century saw occasional bubbles in canals and railroads. Share prices entered a bubble in 1929; gold, silver and oil in 1980, and Japan and Taiwan in 1989. In 2000 there was a huge bubble in one sector: TMT, or technology, media and telecommunications. This time around, since 2002, everything has gone up: home prices, real estate and art prices, stock prices, commodity prices and even, until recently, bonds.   We are going to see a gradual narrowing of the bubbles, or perhaps they will all break at the same time. The Dow Jones industrials and the S&P 500 are in an incredible bubble phase. For foreign investors, the rise in the S&P mostly has been offset by weakness in the dollar, so U.S. assets aren't terribly expensive relative to other assets. Sure, the market sells for only 15-16 times forecast earnings. But if you take out the gains in energy and financial-sector earnings, the market is selling above 20 times earnings. Given that you can buy a two-year Treasury note yielding 5%, that is not an attractive valuation. I would rather be a seller of the stocks around the world than a buyer here.     Q: Is there any market you consider attractive?   A: I still own a few stocks in Asia, where the fundamentals are favorable. In countries such as Malaysia [see page M12], Indonesia, Singapore and Thailand, valuations are attractive compared to the the local yield on bank deposits and bonds. The same goes for Japan. But those markets have become correlated with the U.S., so if the S&P goes down 5%-10%, nothing much will go up. If the S&P drops 10%, emerging markets easily could drop 20% or more.     Q: Are you predicting a 10% decline in the S&P?   A: Yes. The S&P either will really begin to correct, or continue to move up, perhaps until August, and, like in 1987, have a very sharp setback in the second half. The U.S. economy has been in an expansion mode for 67 months, starting in November 2001. The expansion is old. The stock market hasn't had a 10% correction since March 2003, which also is unusual. There are lots of symptoms of speculation around. Share buybacks are great because they are driving up the share market, people say. But there were enormous share buybacks and equity shrinkage in 1985, '86 and '87, and the market dropped 40% between the summer of '87 and October of that year. The shrinkage of equities frequently is a negative rather than a positive sign.     Q: What, if anything, are you buying these days?   A: Thailand is a relatively inexpensive market. The outlook is not brilliant, but you can find a lot of stocks that sell for 8-12 times earnings and yield around 6%. I still like Thai Reinsurance [THRE.Thailand], which I've mentioned in the past, and DSG International [DSGT.Thailand], which makes disposable diapers. Then there's Singapore Airport Terminal Services [SATS.Singapore], a catering company. In January I recommended Oishi Group [OISHI.Thailand] and it went down. The risk is minimal at current levels. The company sells fruit juice. I also like Tipco Foods [TIPCO.Thailand].     Q: In January you also recommended shorting the 30-year bond. We presume you're still bearish.   A: Yes, although near-term these bonds are oversold. It is a great error to think that in an economic slowdown, the rate of inflation automatically drops. Don't tell me your cost of living is increasing by only 2% a year. On the commodity side I recommended cotton, which may be at the beginning of a sizable upward move. I still like it. The same goes for sugar, where the downside risk is low.   As for a new idea, I'd try to short U.S. retailers, excluding Wal-Mart [WMT]. You can use the consumer discretionary SPDR [XLY]. It won't do as badly as the rest of the industry. There will come a time when middle-class households exact their revenge and do better relative to the Wall Street crowd. The problem with Wall Street is this: If you take away the fees earned by structured products and investment banking and mergers and acquisitions, there won't be much left. I admire Wall Street and the banking system, which when faced with collapsing commission rates invented structured products from which to earn so much. But one day it will dawn even on financial institutions, and on state pension funds, that they are paying a high fee for a very large basket of hedge funds. Some hedge funds are superstars. But out of 7,000 hedge funds, not all are superstars. And it's not just hedge funds. The whole system is geared to taking a lot of money out of the pockets of clients. Where are the customers' planes?     Q: Excellent question. Let's talk about China.   A: The Chinese stock market has quadrupled from its low in June 2005, when it was at a relatively depressed level. Clearly the market is in a bubble, but following a correction it might make a new high. In 1987 we had a bubble in Japan and Taiwan. The Taiwan market crashed, falling 50%, and then went up another four times to its final peak.   Economically, China is expanding at breakneck speed. Industrial production is rising by 16% to 18% per annum. At some stage there will be indigestion and disappointing news. The rate of inflation in China has accelerated quite a bit. Food prices have become a larger percentage of total consumption. Look, everything has reached the bubble stage, but bubbles can grow bigger. If you step into the market and buy here, use stop-loss orders.     Thanks, Marc.   OSCAR SCHAFER     Q: Is there much juice left in this market, Oscar?   Schafer: The stock market is not going to do all that much the rest of the year, despite all the talking heads gabbing about new highs. The major averages are up less than 10%. As for the economy, one of the three bears is going to get Goldilocks one of these days. Interest rates are going up, but they're rising due to demand for money, not inflation. That means earnings will be OK, and so should the stock market. But if the Goldilocks economy -- not too hot, not to cold -- is challenged, the stock market will have a problem.     Q: But not this year.   A: Right. I read about banks lending to LBO firms with no covenants, and investment banks having outsized bridge-loan commitments relative to their equity. Then there are liar loans, where people fib about their income. The whole housing situation is scary. But unless things change radically, as long as people are employed, the market will climb the wall of worry or stay where it is.     Q: How does your portfolio look these days?   A: We're about 100% long and 30% short. We're acting like a true hedge fund, having made almost 6% on the short side.   Is there much worth selling short?   No. It continues to be a tough place to pick your spots because the economy is pretty strong. There are too many hedge funds shorting the same kinds of stocks. We don't talk about our short ideas, but I have two long ideas. In last year's Midyear Roundtable I recommended Kos Pharmaceuticals at 37. In November Abbott Laboratories [ABT] announced it would acquire Kos for 78 a share. Endo Pharmaceuticals Holdings [ENDP] is similar to Kos in that concerns about its main product are overstated. It has a significant net cash position, strong product franchises and an underappreciated pipeline; a strong management team and a stock that is trading at a significant discount to other specialty-pharmaceutical companies. Endo could be a very attractive asset for Abbott or other strategic buyers.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Toyota Is Best-Selling US Auto Brand For First Time -Report
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--While Ford and Chevrolet continue their perennial fight for dominance in the U.S. car and truck market, Toyota Motor Corp. (TM) has slipped in under the radar to claim the top spot as the best-selling automotive brand in the country, The Detroit News reported Saturday.   Through May, Toyota led all brands with U.S. unit sales of 954,000 vehicles, a razor-thin 5,200 units ahead of General Motors Corp.'s (GM) Chevy brand and 40,000 better than the Ford Motor Co.'s (F) Ford brand, the newspaper said.   The Toyota brand's lead is far wider when it comes to all-important retail sales, which exclude low-margin sales to car rental companies and other fleets, according to the paper. In April, Toyota's namesake brand claimed 15.8% of the U.S. retail vehicle market, compared with 11.9% for Chevy and 11.1% for Ford, according to an analysis of national sales transaction data prepared for The Detroit News by R.L. Polk & Co.   The Toyota figures include its youth-oriented Scion models because they are sold through the same dealer network, but exclude its luxury Lexus brand, the paper said.   Toyota spokesman Irv Miller said the company is aware of its position in the market but believes there is little value in leveraging it for promotional purposes because most Toyota buyers are more interested in attributes such as quality and fuel economy, the paper reported. In the same vein, Toyota has played down the fact that it passed GM in worldwide sales volumes in the first quarter of this year.     Newspaper Web site: www.detroitnews.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 06:31 ET (10:31 GMT)

Headline: Vodafone Chief Exec's Pay Rises 18% -FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Arun Sarin, chief executive of Vodafone (VOD.LN), saw his pay package rise nearly 20% in the last financial year as he achieved many of the mobile phone group's internal performance targets, the Financial Times reported Saturday.   The newspaper said that Sarin, who received GBP2.89 million in shares from a long-term incentive program, took home more than GBP3.2 million, a rise of 18% on last year after receiving GBP1.27 million in salary and GBP1.93 million in share awards, according to figures from the group's annual report, published Friday.   Last month Vodafone beat market forecasts after announcing operating profit would be potentially flat in the coming financial year while it forecast that 2008 sales would exceed some estimates because of higher growth in emerging markets, the FT reported.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     Order free Annual Report for Vodafone Group PLC  Visit http://djnweurope.ar.wilink.com/?ticker=GB00B16GWD56 or call +44 (0)208 391 6028  (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 07:12 ET (11:12 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) High-Powered Battery
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jack Willoughby   The name Battery Ventures probably isn't familiar to most investors. But the Waltham, Mass., venture-capital firm has a strong knack for a tricky business and, over the past year, has helped bring several technology and communications companies public.   "It's not so much that the tech sector is strong," says Morgan Jones, the company's communications engineering partner. "The companies coming public now have grown up strong and profitable in a challenging environment;[they're] built to last. During the boom years, they were built to be sold."   Maybe that's why, as Jones notes: "In the past two years, less than 26 technology offerings were made, only a fraction of the 150-plus-deal years familiar during the dot-com boom." And the newest deals are likely to generate average returns in the teens to low 20s, rather than the 30%-plus common in the 'Nineties.   Battery Ventures, like many other venture-capital firms, struggled and slimmed down after the tech bubble burst and 9/11 further hurt the market. The company, which once had 65 employees, now has 53. At the same time, it's broadened its scope, recruiting people qualified to look at a wider variety of companies in tech and related fields. "It's a question of taking what you know and applying it to new and unexpected areas," says Battery Ventures general partner Thomas Crotty. "Embracing what you know but continuing to extend into new areas less crowded with competitors." The company also has widened its geographic reach. It now has offices on both U.S. coasts, Israel and India. Soon, it hopes to plant its flag in China.   The venture-capital game has never been easy, but now there's a new twist. With all the private-equity money sloshing around and with Sarbanes-Oxley rules in effect, some entrepreneurs prefer to sell their businesses privately or to list them overseas, rather than in the U.S. These people worry about the cost and time needed to meet Sarbox's extensive disclosure regulations and are concerned about the legal liability the law imposes on top executives.   Case in point: Battery owns a stake in a small Indian firm called Tejas Networks, which builds high-quality, low-priced equipment for Nortel. "Five years ago, there would be no question. The Tejas Networks IPO would have been done via the Nasdaq," says Crotty. "When it does come public, it will be going on the Bombay exchange."   Such changes add to the challenge that Battery Ventures faces. "Sure we have a number of deals in registration," adds Crotty, a Notre Dame grad with an MBA from Wharton. "But the ones in registration only represent the survivors. For each one, there is at least another that we let die as we worked our way through the tech slowdown."   In the pipeline right now are several potential IPOs, including one for Netezza, a maker of data-warehouse devices and another for BladeLogic, a computer-server management specialist, Both have already filed to go public.   Each year, Battery Ventures looks at up to 4,500 companies that potentially could go public. The list quickly is winnowed to a couple of hundred. This group, in turn, is trimmed to 50 with the potential to become "hot" deals. A Battery Ventures principal and two assistants are assigned to each of these. Their aim: to nurture the company through the IPO startup process and successive rounds of financing. At every step of the process, a three-person investment committee scrutinizes the project. The panel wants to ensure that the principal and assistants don't "go native" -- become so enamored of a prospect that they're blinded to its risks.   Battery Ventures usually is approached by companies dreaming of a public offering. But, frequently, it takes the initiative. Sparked by something they, say, read in the newspapers, its associates will solicit promising startups. The firm also will draw candidates for the public market from later-stage buyout and private-equity firms, such as Boston's TA Associates.   "They're not the first names you see on those high-profile deals, but they have earned a really well-respected name in the business," says Donald Stanley, Battery Ventures' former chief financial officer, who now works for another VC firm. "They have a willingness to take on risk that's not obvious. Anyone can do a tech deal when everyone else is doing them, but Battery Ventures is often in the lead."   The firm oversees $2.2 billion in investments, via seven venture-capital funds, open mainly to institutions, which normally invest $10 million to $15 million for 10 years. Of the seven funds, six have returns that are in the first quartile of their peers, according to the company, based on their showings over their durations. The net returns to investors have ranged from 13% to 165%.     Having $2.2 billion to invest would have been a stunning luxury when Battery Ventures was founded 24 years ago by Rick Frisbie, an investment pro with both a venture-capital and law background.   To kick-start the operation, Battery Ventures first used the Yankee Group's technology analysts, but soon came to rely on its own staff. Frisbie remains as a partner, and an adviser on management and strategy. "At the time, we were one of the few firms that specifically focused on information technology and communications software," he recalls.   From the beginning, the company emphasized teamwork. Says Frisbie: "The idea has been to build a franchise in which people believe, not to glorify individual dealmakers. This team approach is difficult, because the venture-capital field is dominated by individualists." This means that no one person can block -- or push through -- a deal. At the same time, he says, it means that, "to be successful at Battery Ventures, you can't be a wimp, because you'll never get any deals done. You have to have confidence in your own ability. But not be arrogant. We want to have guys around who are fun. Around here, even in the most serious meeting, you're going to hear laughter."   As is the norm in its high-risk, high-reward business, Battery Ventures has both feasted on some fat successes and unhappily gnawed on "bagels," as failed deals are known (an allusion to zero).   The company's biggest deal was for Qtera, an optic-networking outfit sold to Nortel for about $3.25 billion. Battery's return on the sale, done at the height of the tech bubble, was $1 billion on an $8.4 million investment. Morgan Jones, who has engineering degrees from Harvard and Stanford, "was instrumental in helping to start the company," recalls Stanley. "Qtera's founders thought so much of him and his contribution that they cut him a significant piece of their own positions in the company at the time of the sale."   In late 2000, Battery Ventures teamed with the Blackstone Group to buy the money-losing London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange. A year later, a revitalized LIFFE was sold for $800 million to Euronext, earning Battery and Blackstone more than $100 million apiece on an investment one-third the size.   Another triumph came in 2004, when Battery Ventures became an investor in Fingerhut, a Minneapolis-based direct marketer that was liquidated after suffering large losses.   With advice and capital from Battery Ventures and Bain & Co., the company's managers turned Fingerhut into a money-maker again. The key was employing a state-of-the-art computer system to reconnect sales, credit, collections and marketing, to get the most from Fingerhut's very loyal customer base, many of them homemakers with low incomes.   Brian Smith, Fingerhut's CEO, says that Battery Ventures knew enough about operations to improve the business, but had the discretion to let its managers manage. Last year, Fingerhut produced "very healthy profit" on $310 million in revenue. The company, in which Battery Ventures still has about a 20% stake, thinks it can grow at a 25% annual clip over the next five years.   A newer IPO that's worked out was for MetroPCS (ticker: PCS), which raised $1.3 billion. The wireless concern's stock was priced at $23 two months ago. It's now in the 30s.     Not everything succeeds. Last October, Battery Ventures helped bring fiberoptics specialist Optium public in a $91 million transaction. The shares (OPTM) priced at 17.50 and and got as high as 27 before they began tumbling on concern about earnings; the stock recently was at 11.30.   And, lest anyone in the firm get too cocky, Battery Ventures keeps the icon of its all-time, highest-profile catastrophe on display in the office -- a sock puppet from the ill-fated Pets.com.   Says Crotty: "Half of the deals you do you take a complete loss or get cents on the dollar back. On roughly one in four, you make between one- two- three-times your money back. The remaining one in four deals you hope to make 8 to 10 times invested capital or even higher to make up for the losses."   For nearly a quarter-century, Battery Ventures has been able to make this treacherous math work. And, given its funds' history, it doesn't look as if it's lost its touch.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining more than 5% of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from June 7 through 13.   Source: Dow Jones Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Ceridian (CEN)   William Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management, Ceridian's largest shareholder, said it had hired Lazard Freres to seek alternatives to Ceridian's agreement to be sold for $5.3 billion, or $36 a share, to Thomas H. Lee Partners and Fidelity National Financial (ticker: FNF). Ackman said that the best course would be " . . . a sale of the entire company at a higher price; a sale or separation of one or both of the company's main operating units; and/or a recapitalization, dividend or self-tender transaction where significant value can be returned to stockholders, whether in combination with a broader transaction or otherwise."   Pershing Square holds 21,432,734 shares (14.9% of the total outstanding).     Investment Technology Group (ITG)   D.E. Shaw Laminar Portfolios said it wants the company to evaluate strategic alternatives. Shaw urged the board to consider a sale of some or all of ITG's businesses to a strategic or financial buyer. D.E. Shaw owns about 2.73 million shares (6.2%).     Vertrue (VTRU)   Ramius Capital Group opposes the proposed acquisition of the company by One Equity Partners, saying the $48.50-a-share offer price is too low. Ramius Capital said the terms of the acquisition don't reflect the intrinsic value of the company and added that it reserves its right to seek appraisal of the fair value of its investment. Ramius Capital holds 522,400 shares (5.4%).     Inter-Tel (INTL)   Inter-Tel's former CEO, Steven G. Mihaylo, said he had filed a preliminary proxy statement in connection with the 2007 special meeting of shareholders. Mihaylo, the company's founder and largest shareholder, is soliciting proxies from shareholders to vote against a proposed buyout by Mitel Networks. Mihaylo, who supports a recapitalization plan for the company, owns 5.2 million shares (19%). The special meeting is scheduled for June 29.     NetManage (NETM)   JGD Management has been in negotiations with NetManage regarding a confidentiality agreement for exchanges of information between the two. It's expected that any such agreement would contain certain standstill provisions, which limit how much stock an investor can buy for a certain period. JGD Management, a New York-based hedge fund, owns 489,799 shares (5.1%).     Yardville National Bancorp (YANB)   Investor Lawrence B. Seidman said he had reached a settlement with the company, under which he is ending his proxy contest for three board seats. The settlement will end outstanding legal disputes between Seidman and Yardville if the company's pending merger goes through.   As part of the deal, Yardville will pay about $100,000 to Seidman, who owns about 1 million shares (9.26%).     Original Filings     Savannah Bancorp (SAVB)   Sandler O'Neill Asset Management reported ownership of 330,216 shares (5.66%), after buying 110,216 from April 24 to June 6 at $24.55 to $25.80 apiece.     Increases in Holdings     Visteon (VC)   Hedge fund Pardus Capital Management raised its holdings to 23.5 million shares (18.1%) by buying 300,000 on June 8 at an average price of $7.98.     Coinstar (CSTR)   Funds including Shamrock Activist Value increased their position to 2,316,445 shares (8.3%) from the 2,022,665 (7.3%) reported on Feb. 27.     Decreases in Holdings     GenCorp (GY)   Pirate Capital trimmed its stake to 2.72 million shares (4.8%) from the 3.83 million (6.8%) reported on May 23.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Barron's Roundtable: Room To Run -5-
Story: Black: Let's start with valuation. I'm sticking with my '07 estimate for S&P 500 earnings: $87, up 6.7% for the year. That means the index, at current levels, sells for 17.6 times earnings. The market is about 10% overvalued. That doesn't mean it can't go up, but the median P/E [price-earnings multiple] has been 16 since 1946. As for individual companies, we screen 11,000 stocks, and there just aren't that many low-P/E, low-price-to-enterprise-value stocks out there. Many that show up on our screens, like the Bermuda reinsurers, we already own. At the beginning of the year, oil stocks were cheap. They are not cheap any more at 10, 11, 12 times forward earnings, and 6, 7, 7.5 times discretionary cash flow. It's the same with metals stocks. At 11-12 times expected earnings, they're not cheap. For a deep-value player, this has been one of the toughest markets in a long time. You have to find fallen angels or obscure companies.   Another problem is the casino mentality of many market players. Between the hedge funds trading in and out and the private-equity people chasing stocks at very inflated multiples of price to enterprise value, it reminds me a bit of the Michael Milken era -- the leveraged-buyout binge of the late 1980s. And there seems to be no fear. Look at the bond market. Investment-grade debt yields only 83 basis points over Treasuries, the lowest spread in nine years. [A basis point is one one-hundredth of a percentage point.] High-yield debt is 232 points over Treasuries -- a record low. There is no risk premium built into equities, and there is certainly none built into bonds. This belies the real economy, which slowed in the first quarter to about 0.6% growth.     Q: How do you explain the divergence?   A: The world is awash in liquidity. Last year there were $3.7 trillion worth of deals done, followed by another trillion in the first quarter of this year. All those stocks were retired, and the money has to get recycled. As supply shrinks, demand seems to increase, and it clears the market at higher prices. The run-up in prices is more of a technical event than one based on the fundamental earnings power of companies.     Q: What could break this cycle?   A: You almost need to have a hedge fund blow up, or a couple of private-equity deals go south. The private-equity business is more of a fee-gathering business now than an investment-performance business. If you attract a lot of money and you have to pay higher prices, returns at the margin go down.   One more thing: I criticized Ben Bernanke last June for talking too much after he became chairman of the Fed. In hindsight, he has done an excellent job. He is trying to navigate a delicate balance between ramping inflation down and avoiding a recession. Core inflation is 2.3% year over year, above the Fed's 2% comfort zone, so Bernanke is not going to cut rates as quickly as everyone thought. But he is not going to lift rates, as inflation isn't accelerating. If the economy stagnates, he will cut, choosing a whiff of inflation over recession. But I don't expect it to stagnate; even with $3.15 gasoline and a weaker housing market, the consumer is spending. The stock market is rising, and overall household net worth is near record highs.     Q: Now that you have apologized officially to Mr. Bernanke, tell us about a fallen angel you like.   A: I recommended American Eagle Outfitters [AEO], an apparel retailer, at the 2006 Roundtable. It had a big run, we sold, and the stock has fallen back to 27.20. In the past five fiscal years, ending Jan. 31, revenue has compounded by 19.1% a year. Operating income has grown to $587 million from $158 million, up 38% a year. Operating margins have climbed to 21% from 11.4%. Sales per square foot have risen to $642 from $460. Earnings per share are $1.70, up from 46 cents. Return on equity is 28%. There is no debt and $827 million in cash on the balance sheet.   With those numbers, the stock should get more respect.   American Eagle is the Rodney Dangerfield of retail stocks. It has 914 stores. Its bread and butter is the American Eagle stores, which cater to 15-to-25-year-olds. Girls generate 65% of the revenue, boys 35%. A second format, Martin+Osa, caters to 25-to-40-year-olds. This is not a fashion-oriented business. They like to say they are on trend, but they are not ahead. They compete against Abercrombie & Fitch [ANF] and its Hollister unit and Pacific Sunwear [PSUN], and at the lower end, Aeropostale [ARO].   American Eagle has a lot of customer-relations databases. They put in a new enterprise-software system and point-of-sale systems. The typical customer buys two items for $20 apiece, or $40 per visit. The company wants to grow square footage by 9% to 11% a year, mostly at American Eagle stores, and has budgeted for 4% to 5% comparable-store growth. Operating margins long term probably can exceed 21%, which gives you earnings-per-share growth of 15% or more.     Q: What are your estimates for fiscal '08?   A: Revenue will rise 15%, to $3.2 billion. Divide $439 million in net income by 225 million fully diluted shares, and you get $1.95 a share for the year, versus $1.70 in fiscal '07. They probably will buy back more shares. The stock trades for 13.9 times fiscal '08 estimates. The company will generate about $290 million in free cash flow this year, up from $276 million. This is a money machine. If they don't buy back shares, their cash position will increase to more than $1 billion. In the year ending January '09, earnings could grow to $2.25 a share. The P/E on fiscal '09 is 12.1. Many large-cap growth companies -- the Coca-Colas and Campbell Soups -- are 5%-6% top-line growers and 9%-10% bottom-line growers, and they're trading at 18 and 20 times earnings. American Eagle is ridiculously cheap. Yes, gasoline prices are up, but the company hasn't seen any decline in store traffic. The stock has come down substantially. This is a good entry point.     Q: How about another name, Scott?   A: ChipMOS Technologies [IMOS] is a small Taiwan company that trades in the U.S. via American depositary receipts. It sells for 6.49, and there are 73.8 million fully diluted shares, for a market capitalization of $479 million. Semiconductor testing is 60% of revenue, and assembly 40%. ChipMOS has a broad base of customers, including Hynix, Samsung, National Semiconductor, Sharp, Toshiba and Fujitsu. It serves four different markets: DRAM, flash memory, liquid-crystal display and mixed-signal. Consumer electronics is a big driver of growth.   In the past, the business has been cyclical. Earnings peaked at 79 cents a share in 2004, and return on equity at 18.8% Last year they did 74 cents and 16.7% ROE. Earnings will rebound this year. Book value is $8.55 a share, so the stock sells at 0.76 times book. There is almost no goodwill. The debt-to-equity ratio is about 0.5. Free cash flow could be about $50 million this year. ROE will come in around 11%-12% but is on track to get above 15%.     Q: Why the downturn?   A: Revenue was up 31% in the first quarter, though earnings were down a few pennies as the average selling prices on test and assembly fell 5% to 10%. Conservatively, ChipMOS will do about $750 million in revenue this year. It could net $71 million after taxes, or 96 cents, fully diluted. If margins come back a little, it could do $1.04. The midpoint is $1, so let's use that. The stock trades for roughly 6.5 times earnings. It's cheap. And 39% of current capacity is booked through 2009 on long-term contracts. It would help if DRAM prices firmed a bit, but we own Micron [MU], and the same dynamics that might make that go up 15%-20% could push this stock up two or three points, or 35%-40%.     Thanks, Scott.     JOHN NEFF     Q: Are you still sanguine about the market, John?   Neff: I'm using $100 for S&P 500 earnings in 2008, which would mean a gain of about 8%, based on my '07 estimates. The market sells for 15.3 times my '08 number, which isn't outlandish, particularly relative to the alternatives. The bond market doesn't look attractive, and commercial real estate has had an awfully good move and in some cases looks overdone. The stock market looks OK until we have a recession. An 8% increase in earnings and a 2% dividend yield give you a total return of 10%. That's attractive. A couple of things bother me, though.     Q: Such as?   A: One is the abundance, if not overabundance, of private-equity deals and leveraged buyouts. You're creating a great deal of debt among target companies, and inviting the possibility of some sort of accident, given that higher leverage. Also, I'm bothered by the outrageous investment fees charged by so-called hedge funds. Twenty percent of profits and 1% or 2% of assets in fees is outlandish in terms of a money manager's ability to succeed by enough of a margin to make a good return for the shareholder. It's just too much to give away. Some funds are going to have to take bigger risks, which could lead to bad headlines that disturb the confidence of the market, as "Wrong-Term" Capital Management did in the 1990s. Having said all that, the subprime-mortgage problem was bad, but didn't affect the market's confidence or performance. I'm still in the market, though I've taken something off the top since stocks moved up. The accounts I manage are 11% to 15% in cash. I can't find anything to buy. But stand by.     Q: Uh-oh. You have been a long-time bull on housing. Do you see any signs of recovery in that market?   A: The housing market is looking for a bottom. Maybe it will happen this year, and you'll crawl out next year. No. 1, housing has become more affordable, particularly on the coasts. No. 2, mortgage rates are still pretty friendly. No. 3, the economy is decent and there is a growing demand for new houses. I've got about 7% in home-building stocks.     Q: Are you buying, selling or waiting it out?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UBI Banca Targets EUR1.4B Net In 2010, Mulls Higher Div
Story: MILAN (Dow Jones)--Italian bank Unione di Banche Italiane ScpA (UBI.MJ), or UBI Banca said late Friday it is targeting a net profit of over EUR1.4 billion in 2010, net of nonrecurring items, adding that the plan doesn't include the effect of potential partnership in the non-life bancassurance, consumer finance and corporate banking units.   UBI Banca, Italy's fourth largest bank with a market capitalization of EUR13.7 billion, also said it has EUR1 billion of free capital to give to shareholders.   The board of directors of UBI Banca met Friday to approve its first business plan for the 2007-2010 period since the merger between Banche Popolari Unite SCARL and Banca Lombarda e Piemontese was effective.   The banks said in the statement that results don't include the effects of the allocation of the merger differences, which is estimated could have a net negative impact of around EUR100 million over the business plan period.   Bergamo-based UBI Banca also said it aims to pay a dividend of at least EUR1.30 per share in 2010, up from EUR0.80 per share in 2006.   It also said that annual synergies from the merger should be more than EUR400 million in 2010, ahead of initial estimates of EUR365 million.   In the last six months UBI Banca shares were unchanged, undeperforming the S&PMib index.   UBI Banca also said it will reorganize its asset management activities by merging its Capitalgest unit into BPU Pramerica as well as extend its partnership with Prudential Plc's (PRU.LN) to the entire group. It also said it will keep the strategic partnership with Aviva Plc (AV.LN) and Italian insurer Cattolica Assicurazioni SpA (CASS.MI) in life bancassurance business as well as extend to the entire company the non-life bancassurance of BPU Assicurazioni.   Company website: http://www.ubibanca.it   -By Sabrina Cohen, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 02 5821 9906; sabrina.cohen@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 08:37 ET (12:37 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Other Voices: For Whom Do The Bells Toll?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kevin Duffy   Market tops are seductive, crowded, raucous, faith-based affairs. Central bankers are lionized, technologists appreciated, businessmen lauded as they fill the government's coffers, gurus and charlatans elevated and economists cheered as they explain why the business cycle is no longer relevant. Capital is cheap and plentiful, taken for granted and abused.   Bottoms are grueling, demoralizing, faith-shattering and so lonely you can hear a pin drop. As bust exposes the boom's sins, the curtain is pulled back on its leading authorities. Risk-taking is punished, scandals revealed and scapegoats pilloried. Liquidity dries up, bids disappear and capital becomes precious again.   Where are we now? Despite the recent spike in 10-year Treasury yields and an uptick in volatility, investors appear unflappable. Guest commentary on CNBC continues to be universally upbeat. Even reporters routinely interject their own optimism and scoff at the occasional skeptic.   Earlier this year, strategists at 12 large firms were unanimous in forecasting higher stock prices this year for the first time since the end of 2000 (when the S&P 500 proceeded to drop 33% in two years). Over the past 453 weeks, Investors Intelligence's poll of investment-newsletter editors has recorded more bears than bulls just nine times.   Money-market-fund balances are near an all-time low, 21.1% of mutual-fund and exchange-traded-fund assets. The Investment Company Institute reports equity-fund cash levels are at a paltry 3.7%, breaking the historic low of 3.9% set in May 1972 (prior to the worst bear market since the Great Depression).   Gurus have emerged to tell the masses what they want to hear. While Mad Money host James Cramer "just wants to make you rich," money manager and Forbes columnist Ken Fisher insists he invests by "knowing what others don't." Both recently published best-selling books, and both are very bullish.   A record $1.55 trillion in domestic takeovers took place in 2006, according to Standard & Poor's, and deal flow is running 60% higher this year. The "Bloomberg 20" investment banks raked in $34.9 billion in fees last year from mergers and acquisitions, up from $10.6 billion in 2002.   An estimated $7 billion resides in bear-fund and short ETF assets against $7.0 trillion in stock-fund assets. The Strunk Short Index used to track 25 short-bias hedge funds; that number has dwindled to eight or nine out of more than 9,200 hedge funds.   Speculators convinced of enduring asset inflation are standing-room only at the credit casino. The beneficiaries have been lenders, brokers, real-estate developers, money shufflers and purveyors of discretionary consumer items. From 2001-2005, 40% of new jobs were provided by real estate and construction. Over 45% of corporate profits now come from financing activity. The No. 1 S&P 500 sector weighting is financials at 22%. Of the current Forbes 400 members, 140 made their fortunes from real estate, investments or finance. Today 24 of 72 major sports stadiums have granted naming rights to financial firms, 14 of them banks. (Recall that 19% of the Stadium Class of 2000 -- including PSINet Stadium and Enron Field -- went bankrupt within five years.)   The residential real-estate bubble of 23 months ago has transmogrified into a professional-speculator bubble, adding appendages such as commercial real estate, hedge funds, and private equity. These "alternative investments" have been driven up by institutions attempting to generate outsized returns in a yield-starved world, simply by applying leverage.   There are now more bells ringing than at an Austrian downhill ski race.   On Feb. 9, Fortress Investment Group became the first hedge-fund manager to go public in the U.S. Although the offering was not exactly shareholder-friendly (negative book value, rich valuation, principals selling shares), "FIG" soared 68% its first day.   "The New King of Wall Street," Blackstone CEO Steve Schwarzman, graced the March 5 cover of Fortune, which featured the top 10 private-equity players. Blackstone recently sold a $3 billion stake to the Chinese and is expected to go public next week. A successful offering could raise Schwarzman's net worth to $12 billion, vaulting him from 73rd on the Forbes 400 into the top 20.   Goldman Sachs, arguably the greatest beneficiary of the booms in trading, hedge funds, private equity and structured finance, grew its balance sheet 21.8% annually over the past five years. During the February quarter, total assets exceeded total bank credit at the Federal Reserve for the first time.   "Liquidity" has become the siren song of the bulls. BusinessWeek apotheosized this rationale with its Feb. 19 cover, "It's a Low, Low, Low, Low-Rate World: Why money may stay cheap longer than you think."   With so many on Wall Street singing the same optimistic tune, is it time to get defensive and grab a chair before the music stops? Perhaps the adage by the late Humphrey Neill, the father of modern contrarian theory, applies here: "When everybody thinks alike, everyone is likely to be wrong."   ---   Kevin Duffy is a principal of Bearing Asset Management.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:02 ET (04:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Barron's Roundtable: Room To Run -2-
Story: A: In 2009 or '10. Deals with covenant-lite provisions can cover two years of economic challenges. At the end someone will overpay, there will be an episode of insider trading, or something. A lot of garbage will surface. My major concern about deals is no different than my major concern about the stock market: There is so much leverage, and the use of derivatives has built in so much leverage below the surface. Also, asset managers, even ordinary money managers, are telling pension plans and other clients, "Let me be your hedge fund. Give me a dollar and I'll buy $130 of stocks, but I'll short $30 worth." The dynamics are in place for a stress test of the whole system. That could be Bernanke's first big test.     Q: What are you buying?   A: We see a big catalyst in Aruze [6425.Japan], a Japanese operator of pachinko parlors. Gambling is coming to Japan. Aruze trades at 4060 yen. The company's main asset is 24 million shares of Wynn Resorts [WYNN]. Wynn trades for 95, so you get three-tenths of a share of Wynn per share of Aruze. Add up Aruze's debt, cash and Wynn shares, and you get the underlying business for free.     Q: How is that business doing?   A: There are three speculative elements here. In the next three years, Japan will probably license gambling, and Wynn will have a center-row orchestra seat. Second, the Chinese are passionate gamblers, and will travel to Japan. Third, Goldman Sachs just bought a 9% stake in Aruze.   Next, an update on Cablevision. The stock [CVC] is 35.60, and the value of the company is $50-plus. The controlling shareholders, the Dolan family, have stepped up their buyout price to $36.26 since January, but the value of the company has gone up dramatically. The deal they first had on the table allowed shareholders to get a true-up in value if the company was resold in coming years. That's not the case with this new offer. Cablevision is worth substantially more than its market price, and we think we'll get it.     Q: What else attracts you?   A: The food sector is fertile for deals. At Cadbury Schweppes [CSG], something already is happening. Cadbury has two businesses -- confectionery and beverages. They are selling off the beverage business and will do a major capitalization shrink with the proceeds. The confectionery business fits like a glove with Hershey [HSY] and Kraft Foods [KFT], both of which would be good strategic partners. Cadbury sells for 687 pence in London and the American depositary receipts are 55. We're buying it in London. After the cap shrink and an earnings increase, the stock could be worth 840p.   We also like Hilton Hotels [HLT]. Steve Bollenbach is retiring as CEO. Matt Hart is the new CEO. There are 385 million shares outstanding, and the stock trades for 35.     Q: What is the bullish case for Hilton?   A: The growth in demand of hotel rooms in countries like India. There are about as many hotel rooms in all of India than there are in Las Vegas. Hilton is franchising its brand. There is a global consolidation of the hotel industry, and a lot of private-equity activity. We expect to earn 50% on our money in a couple of years if Hilton agrees to be taken over. If not, at these prices it's a conservative way to play the need for hotel rooms in emerging countries.   Next, Midas [MDS] is an auto-parts company. It's thinly traded, so be careful how you buy it. There are 14.8 million shares outstanding, and the company is converting its business into a franchise model. They brought in Alan Feldman from McDonald's in January 2003, and he has done everything right. He got rid of manufacturing and is trying to rejuvenate the stores. Midas could earn 90 cents a share next year, despite a drop in fees from Europe. It's a 15% to 20% grower. I'm trying to convince management to find another brand to franchise, just as Yum! Brands [YUM] has three brands: Pizza Hut, KFC and Taco Bell.     Q: Smart idea.   A: My next stock is an old friend, Sequa. There are 11.4 million shares outstanding, and an A and B stock. SQA-A trades for 108. The chairman, Norman Alexander, died, and his daughter just became chairman. The play here is simple: Split the company in two. One part will have all the businesses except Chromalloy, which will have 2008 revenue of about $1.3 billion. It can earn a 13% to 14% Ebitda [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization] margins and be worth the value of the entire company, plus debt. Chromalloy, which provides repair and service to airplane engines, is the crown jewel. A Boeing study just said there will be 28,000 planes flying in the next 20 years. Sequa could be worth 50% more.   Finally, we have made a lot of money in wireless telephony over the years. Now we're focused on U.S. Cellular [USM], which has six million customers. In round numbers, '08 earnings will be $3.50 to $4 a share, growing at 25% to 30%. They own 5.5% of a franchise in Los Angeles that is owned by Verizon Communications [VZ]. That alone is worth $800 million. They have a lot of hidden assets. U.S. Cellular is worth about $130 a share based on the price at which Alltel [AT] was sold. It is trading for 88-89. It is 82%-owned by Telephone & Data Systems [TDS]. We own both stocks. Verizon is rolling up its wireless partnerships much the way Sprint Nextel [S] rolled up its partnerships and franchises. At some point Verizon could buy TDS and U.S. Cellular.     Thanks, Mario.   MERYL WITMER     Q: The year must be treating you well, Meryl. Your January picks are up by double-digits.   Witmer: But I have been wrong so far about the broad market. I thought it would be flat to down this year, but it has gone up sharply. Today I have only one stock to recommend, which might be an indication there aren't a lot of cheap names out there. We look at where companies are trading and try to figure out what they are worth and buy with a decent spread. There are fewer companies now with big spreads between price and value. Things are frothy, with private-equity buyers buying up everything.     Q: Have they bought up any of your stocks?   A: FKI [FKI.UK], the British engineering company I recommended in January, has been approached with a buyout offer. One of our favorite stocks now is Heineken, which trades in the Netherlands. We buy the holding-company stock, Heineken Holding, which is less liquid than the operating company but trades at a 14% discount. The holding company sells for around 37 euros, and the operating company for 43.51 euros. They pay the same dividend: 0.60 euros per share per year.     Q: What do you like about Heineken, other than, we presume, the beer?   A: It is one of the best known premium brands in the world, and has an aggressive new CEO, Jean-Francois van Boxmeer, who took the helm in 2005. He is driving growth, innovation and profitability, all with a sense of urgency. There is an opportunity in the stock because many of their initiatives are in the early stages. Current profits understate the earnings power of the company. They are spending money to make money, with the payoff to come later.   Two issues facing Heineken when van Boxmeer became CEO were slowing revenue growth and a lack of focus on costs. On the growth side he has responded with a multi-pronged approach: introducing new products into the market's fastest-growing segment, light beer; channel expansion; entry into faster-growing international markets and innovative packaging, like the five-liter draft.     Q: And on the cost side?   A: Management has announced broad-based cost-cutting programs and tied compensation to the achievement of new cost targets. Aggressive and energized management teams with strong international experience are being injected into Heineken to jolt the culture toward faster decision-making and calculated risk-taking. An example of a successful new-product launch in 2006 was Heineken Premium Light. Combined with Amstel Light and Tecate Light, Heineken's U.S. beer portfolio is one of the strongest in the sweet spot of the industry: imported light beer.   The near-term downside of Heineken Light is that the company is spending heavily to build the brand. Recent expansion into rapidly growing markets such as Russia and Central and Eastern Europe has caused the company to earn less-than-average profits there. Restructuring programs are now under way. Heineken also has renegotiated some partnership agreements in Asia, South America and Canada, which will improve profits and growth potential. The company will grow free cash flow per share from 2 euros in 2006 to easily more than 3 euros after taxes in 2010, we estimate. If they don't make an acquisition, they'll have net cash. Our two-year target is 50 euros to 55 euros.     Q: Aren't beer sales under pressure generally as spirits grow more popular?   A: That is somewhat true, but sales of imported beer are growing rapidly. It is an aspirational product. Imported and specialty beers grew 11% in 2006. Having two Mexican brands -- Tecate and Sol -- also has been great. Heineken will start advertising Tecate heavily. The real key, though, comes from the top down. Our analyst met with the top managers, and they are just so excited and energized to be with the company. Van Boxmeer is only in his mid-40s.     Q: What is the knock on the company, if any?   A: It is not as exposed to emerging markets as Carlsberg, but that is an opportunity.   Cheers, and thanks.   FRED HICKEY   Q: It's been a grim year for the bears, Fred. Have you surrendered yet?   Hickey: The year isn't over. It is a perpendicular market, a manic market, the kind of market that precedes a crash, and that is what I expect.     Q: Care to put a date on it?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Asian Trader: Malaysia's Run Looks Far From Over
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By William J. Holstein and Assif Shameen   Malaysian prime minister Mohamad Mahathir achieved some major coups for his country -- the Petronas Twin Towers, once the world's tallest buildings, loom over central Kuala Lumpur. The new government capital complex at Putrajaya has streets reminiscent of the grand boulevards of ancient Rome. And fast trains run from Kuala Lumpur to a gleaming new airport that Mahathir built.   But Mahathir created a climate of conflict with Anglo-Saxon investors and, in particular, Jewish financiers like George Soros, whom he once blamed for the Asian financial crisis of 1997-1998. Tough controls on foreign capital and curbs on the ringgit's convertibility, imposed after that crisis, didn't help. As a result, Kuala Lumpur's Bursa (stock market) has languished in global investing's backwaters for a decade. "After the Asian crisis, all my American clients simply closed their Malaysian accounts," recalls Cheston Chua, then a broker and now research chief for ECMLibra Avenue Securities, Malaysia's second-largest investment bank.   But now Mahathir is 82 and has been in and out of hospitals for heart-related problems. His successor, Abdullah Badawi, is beginning to steer a different course by easing capital controls and restrictions on foreign investments and moving away from Mahathir's "crony capitalism."   External trends also are blowing in the Bursa's favor -- a surge in commodity prices has been a boon because palm oil may become Asia's equivalent of ethanol. A political crisis in nearby Thailand means that fund managers are shifting dollars allocated for Southeast Asia into Malaysia. And the market's conviction that China is overpriced means that some funds are moving to less speculative markets. Malaysia's average P/E is about 17, versus 45 to 50 on China's frothy domestic exchanges. Corporate earnings are growing strongly too -- an estimated 18% this year. Last week, Malaysia reported surprisingly strong GDP growth of 5.3% for the first quarter.   Add it all up and the results are not surprising -- the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index is up 26% in U.S. dollars. Not including the currency effect, the market was up 13% last year and over 20% this year. "The market has been moving up on increased global interest from the beginning of this year," says Lorraine Tan, an equities analyst for Standard & Poor's based in Singapore. Adds Chua Hak Bin, director of Citigroup's Asia Pacific Economics and Market Analysis group: "We expect the overall momentum to be sustained."   Hedge funds, capitalizing on a combined currency and equity play, have helped drive those results. "These guys are smart," says Tan Chong Koay, founder and chief strategist of Pheim Asset Management (Asia), whose assets have just crossed $1 billion. "They know the U.S. currency will weaken and the Asian currencies are strengthening."   The conviction in Kuala Lumpur is that there is room left to run, so the question is which stocks to target. One obvious play: plantation companies such as Sime Darby (ticker: 4197.Malaysia), which is rated overweight by Bear Stearns. At the government's behest, Sime Darby is driving a consolidation of the country's three largest plantation companies and will become the world's largest plantation owner. S&P's Tan says weather conditions are "conducive for another good year" for palm-oil plantations but cautions that "for palm oil to be viable as an alternative, oil prices have to be at a certain level." Palm oil has traditionally been used mostly for cooking and soap, but Europeans are interested in using it as "biofuel" for vehicles because they don't have a large corn crop -- the source of America's ethanol.   Stocks recommended by Bear Stearns include Gamuda (5398.Malaysia), a builder of toll roads and tunnels; IJM (3336.Malaysia), which has construction contracts in Argentina, China, India, Pakistan and the Middle East; and Genting (3182.Malaysia), a gaming company with a license to build a casino in Singapore.   Would-be multinationals such as IJM are run primarily by ethnic Chinese and Indians, who see good prospects outside Malaysia. Wah Seong (5142.Malaysia), for example, a maker of coatings for pipeline and refinery pipes, is working in China and the Mideast. Another favorite is Tenaga Nasonal (5347.Malaysia), the national utility company. With the government having removed a 25% limit on foreign shareholding, its stock is up 38% in a year. Another hot area is financial services, as Malaysian banks such as Malayan Banking (MLYB) carve out roles in global Islamic finance.   One sector to avoid is automotive: the national car company Proton Holdings (5304.Malaysia) is faltering.   Institutions have no trouble buying Malaysian shares in Kuala Lumpur. Individual U.S. investors can trade Southeast Asia funds or pure-play Malaysian funds. One ETF is the iShares MSCI Malaysia Index (EWM) from Barclays Global Investors. And investors interested in a large- and small-cap blend will soon be able to buy into Tan's Pheim Asset Management group through Merrill Lynch.   ---   William J. Holstein is a veteran Asian correspondent. Assif Shameen covers Southeast Asia from Singapore.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Tech Trader: Forget Talk Of 'Net Video; TV Isn't About To Cut To Black
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Eric J. Savitz   I've been thinking a lot about television lately. That hardly makes me unique, of course. Here in Silicon Valley -- and down in L.A., and back in New York -- people are spending a lot of time trying to figure out exactly how and when the Internet is going to kill off the traditional TV business. I'd agree that things really are changing, but not necessarily in the way -- or at the rate --  that the more aggressive proponents of 'Net video would have you believe.   First, let me say that I believe in Internet video; it is here to stay. I'm warming up to Joost, and its cable-like channel structure; I frequently watch clips on YouTube and other sites; I regularly caught up on missed episodes of 24 this season by streaming them free from Fox. As I see it, the problems come when people try to extrapolate from there. 'Net video is nifty, but it won't replace conventional television for a long, long time. If ever.   Despite the new competition, I remain as bullish on the cable-television business now as I was when, in a cover story more than two years ago ("Home Front," March 7, 2005), I declared the industry to be the best bet for investing in the home-media market, or, a few months earlier, I wrote an upbeat cover piece on Comcast ("The Cable Company That Could," Dec. 27, 2004). Skeptics see all sorts of threats to cable, though. They worry that the Bells are going to knock them off with fiber-optic TV systems. They fret about content providers delivering their stuff to consumers directly over the 'Net. They fear that the widespread adoption of digital- video recorders will screw up the TV industry's advertising model. And that's fine. All that worrying is good for investors; it has created cheap stocks.   As I noted on my blog a few days ago, cable analyst Craig Moffett of Bernstein Research recently issued a report that demonstrates just how negative the Street has become on cable stocks. Moffett took a look at the valuations of the nonfinancial stocks in the S&P 500 on the basis of multiples of Ebitda -- earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, a common measure of cash flow -- and found that the stocks in the sector look incredibly cheap. In fact, Moffett contends Comcast (ticker: CMCSA), by far the largest player in pay television, ranks among the 15 cheapest stocks in the S&P 500. Moffett, perhaps the Street's most astute cable analyst, last week raised his price targets on both Comcast and Time Warner Cable (TWC), as well as satellite-TV providers DirecTV (DTV) and EchoStar (DISH).   There are all kinds of reasons to be bullish on cable. Their voice-over Internet Protocol operations are taking market share from the Bells in local phone service. They are direct beneficiaries of plunging prices -- and consumer enthusiasm -- for high def. (If you have a high-def set, you want high-def content.) And they are becoming less-capital-intensive businesses -- ergo, they are becoming cash-generation machines.   OK, you say, but cable is going to get killed, or at least wounded, by the spread of video content on the Internet...isn't it? Well, Internet video poses a challenge for Comcast and its brethren, but it isn't going to kill them off. Or even wound them. Moffett notes that just 1% of all video consumed is delivered via Internet Protocol; 2% is from DVD rentals; traditional TV accounts for the other 97%. He also notes that the number of hours of traditional TV consumed per household keeps rising; in 2006 it hit a record higher of 57.62 hours a week.   Meanwhile, keep in mind that Comcast is the nation's largest provider of broadband Internet access and keeps taking market share from DSL. In any case, I simply do not see very many people pulling the plug on their cable box in favor of Web-based video. If nothing else, it is still too hard to get high-def content over a conventional Internet-access line. Note that the video on iTunes, for instance, is not high-def; in fact, it is below DVD quality. High-def video files are too large for the average 'Net connections to handle in a reasonable time period.   And another thing: Think for a moment about the enormous buzz around the final episode of The Sopranos, which may have been the single most anticipated hour of television since whoever-it-was shot J.R. (I think it involved Phil Leotardo, back when he was whacking guys in the oil patch.) The Sopranos was old-fashioned appointment TV -- even if you had the appointment with your DVR, as I did. It provided something online video lacks: a shared experience. The morning after the episode aired, the chatter about that abrupt cut to black, the suspicious dude at the bar and Meadow's parallel-parking troubles was almost deafening. Let's see a YouTube video do that.   Let me give you a few more factoids on the overstated demise of conventional television. Apple (AAPL) has become cautious in its view of the AppleTV devices, which link iTunes content to flat-panel televisions; Steve Jobs now describes AppleTV as "a hobby," as opposed to a business. And at a media briefing in San Francisco last week, Sony (SNE) said it plans to sell a line of low-priced flat panels via Wal-Mart, Target and other discounters. It was a sign flat panels are going mainsteam -- another positive for cable companies.   And here's one more: There are growing signs that Hollywood is getting comfortable with the concept of releasing movies on DVD and on cable pay-per-view at the same time. The current approach is to release on DVD first, pay-per-view later. But tests show that in places where the new approach has been tried out, DVD sales actually improved. Rentals dipped; but the studios make a lot more on PPV. Good for Comcast, not so good for Netflix (NFLX).   Speaking of Netflix, I noted last week that I was not buying rumors it was about to be acquired by Amazon.com (AMZN). Subsequently, the buzz faded and the stock retreated. Adding pressure: Blockbuster (BBI) last week made an aggressive move to cut prices on DVD-by-mail rental plans. The news was a blow to the Netflix bulls, who had been hoping that Blockbuster would raise prices and enable Netflix to do the same. There is going to be a market for DVD-rental services for years to come, but the sector faces increasing threats from many directions, not the least of which is an expanded set of choices on cable video-on-demand systems, combined with wider adoption of DVRs. There's video everywhere. I don't need to rent more of it. My family dropped Netflix months ago; I see little urgency to come back.   ---   E-mail: eric.savitz@barrons.com.   ---   Visit my blog at blogs.barrons.com/techtraderdaily   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
