Headline: Ebara Develops Effective Cancer Drug Delivery System -Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--Ebara Corp. (6361.TO) has developed a new drug delivery system that enhances the efficacy of cancer treatment by delivering medication only to cancer cells, The Nikkei reported in its Sunday edition.   The medication is first crushed with a laser, and the particles are then covered with a special substance and processed into capsules that are 50-100 nanometers in diameter. The drug can be precisely delivered to cancer cells through holes in the walls of blood vessels they attack that are 200 nanometers in diameter because normal blood vessels have holes that are only several nanometers in diameter, too small to admit the capsules.   The new method can reduce side effects by decreasing the amount of drugs that enter normal blood vessels and circulate around the body.   The manufacturer of pumps and air blowers aims to create a technique for mass-producing cancer medications, possibly in conjunction with a drugmaker.   Pharmaceutical companies that do not have many new drugs and those whose mainstay products are protected by patents that will soon expire are especially interested in enhancing the efficacy of their existing medications with advanced drug delivery systems.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 12:32 ET (16:32 GMT)

Headline: Airbus Exec: 1st A400M Military Plane To Be Delivered On Time
Story: PARIS (Dow Jones)--Airbus remains on track to deliver the first of its A400M military transport planes as scheduled in late 2009 despite some technical hitches on the program, a senior executive said on Friday.   "We don't have a change to the schedule. We don't plan to change it," Juan-Carlos Martinez Saiz, Airbus' executive vice president for military programs, said at a briefing ahead of the Paris Air Show. While some structural problems have been encountered on an engine testing program, Airbus should still deliver the first plane to the French Air Force in late 2009, he said.   The first flight is due in early 2008. Airbus has already delayed the start of  the final assembly of the plane by some three months.   Airbus would be liable to pay penalties if the propeller-powered planes aren't delivered on the dates agreed with its customers. Airbus is a unit of European Aeronautic Defence & Space Co. NV (5730.FR).   Separately, Airbus Military Senior Vice President Richard Thompson said further export orders for the A400M are unlikely before it makes its first flight, but he reported an upturn in interest from potential buyers including the U.S. Airbus has so far taken 192 orders for the plane and expects to sell around another 200.   A delay to the expected delivery date for the military plane would be a serious blow for Airbus, which has incurred huge penalties due to delays on its commercial A380 passenger airplane.   The executives spoke on Friday but EADS embargoed their comments for release Saturday.     Company Web site: http://www.eads.com       -By Rod Stone, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 207 842 9295; rod.stone@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 08:00 ET (12:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Plugged In: UTStarcom Flaming Out
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   Is it time to hang up on UTStarcom?   Probably. The one-time telecom highflier has been mired in one scandal after another. Yet for some value-oriented optimists, it continues to fuel starry-eyed dreams of a turnaround.   Their misguided bets seem to keep the shares from hitting zero, despite the company's failure to file earnings reports since last June and its potential delisting by Nasdaq. That's to say nothing of ongoing investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission into alleged options backdating and insider trading. For good measure, the feds are conducting separate inquiries into various bribery accusations.   The latest red flag to fly at the Alameda, Calif., company was the June 1 resignation of co-founder Ying Wu, who had been head of the company's bulwark China operations. Not only is Wu the linchpin between UTStarcom (ticker: UTSI) and key bureaucrats and business leaders in China -- by far, its most important market -- he also was supposed to be the next CEO.   The shares have plunged 21%, to a recent 5.71, since Wu quit, and are a fraction of their bubble-era high of 87.50, hit in March 2000. UTStarcom was formed by a merger between Wu's Starcom Network Systems, an equipment reseller to Chinese telecoms, and Unitech Telecom, a developer of wireless technology aimed at China, which was started by current UTStarcom CEO Hong Liang Lu. The merged company was backed by Masayoshi Son, the dot-com billionaire who founded Japan's Softbank. It went public in 2000, amassing a post-IPO stock-market value exceeding $5 billion. Son, who hit a home run with his 1990s investment in Yahoo!, was UTStarcom's chairman until March 2003.   The reason for Wu's abrupt departure is unclear. A company spokesman says Wu left because of "differences of opinion in strategy." One thing is clear: He's now free to unload some of his 4.7 million shares.   Frankly, it's darn near impossible to know what's going on, because UTStarcom hasn't provided meaningful information in nearly a year. Even when making mandatory filings, UTStarcom is stealthy. On the Friday before last Christmas, it revealed that it had received an SEC Wells notice -- a notification that the agency may begin enforcement proceedings -- several days before.   The money-losing company (as of its last filing) hasn't filed financials with the SEC for the past three quarters because of a self-imposed internal investigation into options backdating, the spokesman says. The company will update shareholders on the probe when it finally reports financials, says the spokesman, who couldn't say when that would be.   Before the company went quiet, sales of its broadband gear, wireless gear, handsets and services were slipping. But UTStarcom is still out there pitching. A publicist invited me to see its latest wares -- Internet video technology -- at the coming week's megatelecom trade show, NXTcomm, in Chicago. Critics contend that the company's IPTV products are more hype than substance.   Before UTStarcom acquired Audiovox's cellular unit in late 2004, its key product had been its personal-access system, a low-end wireless phone that linked China's swelling urban masses to land lines. As higher-end phones provided by the likes of China Mobile (CHL) became more affordable, sales of UTStarcom's handsets have been in decline. So has the company.   ---   e-mail: mark.veverka@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) The Rise Of The House Of Lehman: -2-
Story: Lehman today earns more money overseas than any investment bank besides Goldman. In 2006, international operations contributed about 37% of revenue. In the second quarter, it was 48%. The firm projects annual growth of investment-banking and capital-markets fees of 7% to 10% in the Americas, 8% to 12% in Europe and 11% to 15% in Asia/Pacific through 2010.   "Over the next two to three years we should be at 50% annually," Fuld says.   Operations in China, where Goldman dominates, also will be expanded. Lehman has viewed China, with its complex regulatory regime, as a banking opportunity advising corporations, whereas in India Lehman expects to employ its full sales, trading and capital-markets capabilities by year's end.   Of course, in some respects, the mythology about Lehman hasn't changed at all over the past decade-and-a-half. It remains a source of takeover speculation. With a market capitalization of about $41 billion and a low price-to-earnings multiple, Lehman is the right size for an acquisition by a major U.S. commercial bank or even one of the investment banks it's starting to challenge in Asia and Europe.   Investors shouldn't buy Lehman shares because of a possible takeover. They should purchase the shares because Lehman, with Fuld at the helm, likely will succeed at punching past skeptics again to become a top-tier international investment bank, adding yet another chapter to the saga. Investors who buy Lehman stock eventually should have their own happy tale to tell.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Up & Down Wall Street: Perils Of Going Public
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Alan Abelson   The tax man cometh! And even before his dreaded knock on the door, the mere premonition of his presence exerts a heart-stopping chill.   Just ask poor Stephen A. Schwarzman, the guiding genius behind the rise of the private-equity goliath Blackstone Group.   Mr. Schwarzman, who has spent countless sweaty hours digging up prospective acquisitions and hammering out deals -- dark and dirty work that he uncomplainingly undertook because of a profound conviction that someone had to do it -- is on the brink of reaping a well-deserved reward for his valiant labors. But that joyous moment has been suddenly shrouded by the long shadow of the tax man.   What makes the sorrow of this rude intrusion all the more poignant is that Mr. Schwarzman, in a noble show of altruism, desired that ordinary folk partake of his good fortune by enabling them, through the agency of an initial public offering, to participate in Blackstone's bountiful future. It speaks volumes about his innate generosity that even the threat of the heavy hand of government has not stayed his determination to share ownership of Blackstone with Jane and John Q. Public.   Alas, even as we write, the Congress is devising ways and means to tamp down the entrepreneurial spirit that burns so brightly in brave risk-takers like Mr. Schwarzman by subjecting them to a painful tax bite.   More specifically, private-equity outfits and hedge funds, once they are publicly traded, will become subject to the 35% tax that your typical corporation must pay, instead of the less-onerous 15% rate levied on capital gains they now enjoy. (Congress is showing unwonted sensitivity, lest it cause too much pain to the fine citizens who run private-equity enterprises and hedge funds, not a few of whom also happen to be substantial campaign contributors, by delaying for five years the day the sharply higher rate would take effect).   To a lesser mortal than Mr. Schwarzman, this prospective change could prove traumatic, for it means that because of the impact on the likely market value of Blackstone, he no longer will be a $7.5 billion man, but merely a $6 billion man. To his credit, this stunning reduction in net worth has not caused him to shed so much as a tear -- at least in public. Nor has it deterred him from unselfishly pressing ahead with Blackstone's IPO.   On that score, we are fully confident that the ogre of a stiffer tax rate down the road will not discourage other private-equity groups and hedge funds from following the lead of Blackstone, and hedge-fund giant Fortress in going public.   For not the least of the commendable things that impels them to take the plunge is an exquisite sense of timing, manifest in an eagerness to cash in while the cashing in is so incredibly good -- a worthy sentiment only intensified by the market's scorching rebound that all but wiped out the damage and the memory of the previous week's tumble.   In short, if by some mischance you fail to get any Blackstone on the offering, don't despair. For unless the portents are all wet, there'll be plenty of opportunity to own a piece of private equity or a hedge fund, whose managers are just as avid as Mr. Schwarzman to share the wealth with even the humblest investor.     There's no inflation -- except for such necessities of daily sustenance as food, gasoline and The Wall Street Journal (which, in case you were too busy having a jolly time at the beach to notice when it was disclosed, next month will fetch $1.50 a copy rather than the current buck). But those are obviously exceptions that prove the point, for none constitutes a component of core inflation, so, in the larger economic scheme of things, how significant can any of them be?   Once again last week, confronted by a disquieting indication that inflation is alive and virulent -- namely, that the producer-price index shot up 0.9% in May -- the Emile Coue chorus in the Street rushed to reassure the investing masses by singing their anthem of everything gets better every day, citing the much more demure 0.2% rise in core producer prices as incontrovertible evidence. And, we're pleased to say, the masses were sufficiently reassured to shrug off the downbeat data and send the market bounding ahead.   And, of course, fresh fuel for the bulls came the very next morning as that same Coue chorus -- or should we more properly call them "core-ists" -- seized on release of the consumer-price index as confirmation that all's well on the inflation front. What better proof, they exulted, than the miserly 0.1% uptick in the CPI -- once you take out pesky items like food and energy. As for the 0.7% rise in the CPI when food and energy are included, "pshaw," they scoffed, that's just the "headline number"!   For the life of us, we must confess, we don't quite understand why "headline" is a pejorative. Do those contemptuous of us benighted souls who award it more serious notice laugh and sneer when a banner headline in their daily proclaims, "War Is Declared" or "World's Tallest Building Collapses" or "Mets Win"?   We've no objection, of course, to anything that makes people happy, even if it's a patently ersatz invention of the Federal Reserve conceived in the '70s when that august body was desperate to find a semantic antidote to the heaving inflation of the time. So at the behest of the then cantankerous chairman, Arthur Burns, it tossed out first energy and then food from the standard calculation of inflation. The result, lo and behold!, was "core inflation," which has served nicely over the years to dim the perception of inflation and buoy spirits on Wall Street, if not in the real world whose inhabitants have to cope best they can with rising prices. (Please don't accuse us of being anti-semantic; our source is the redoubtable Steve Roach, who was one of the economic-spear carriers at the Fed back then.)   And we're also aware that the price of certain commodities has plummeted. DRAM prices, as we noted some weeks back, have suffered a huge markdown. Moreover, the Journal reports that a gram of cocaine, which sold for around $200 barely a decade ago, can be bought these days for as little as $20 (which perhaps tells you more about the no-inflation crew's recreational habits than the legitimacy of their overall analysis).   Bur for ordinary folks like us who don't dabble in DRAMS or do coke, such instances of lower prices might as well be snippets of fluff. The stuff, essential and not so essential both, we must fork over our hard-earned dough to acquire has been getting inexorably more costly for quite a spell now. And to judge by the action in the commodities markets -- wheat at an 11-year high, crude at a nine-month peak, etc. after sad etc. -- we might as well grimace and bear it, and draw what solace we can from the knowledge that core inflation is so meek.     With the stock market in full throttle again, it may seem silly to talk about new ways to sell short, very much akin to holding a serious discussion on new ways to lose money. We mean, why should anyone give a darn?   Well, if curiosity killed a cat, a lack of it has proved innumerably more fatal. Besides, one thing we do know about the stock market is that when everyone is gazing skyward, it's never a bad idea to take a quick peek down. And, stubborn cuss that we are, we can't shake the notion that denial and delusion are positively toxic as long-term investment guides, no matter how rewarding they are when the market's in a manic mood, as it has been these past few years.   Forgive our homilies and we'll get down to the point. Chatting with an old buddy who boasts a long history of successful investing -- mostly, we should note, on the long side -- we got the distinct impression that he was more than slightly antsy about the investment climate. A little impolite probing (we said he's an old buddy) revealed that while he hadn't by any means emptied his portfolio of stocks -- he favors big boring things that, come what may, are apt to be around, as he expects to be, for the next 100 years or so -- he has been seeking a little protection against a bad turn with some short sales.   When pressed for names, he went mute, but finally owned up to being very bearish on commercial REITs, a sector recently covered in a well-wrought negative story in this very magazine by Andrew Bary. We were particularly struck, though, by the medium through which he chose to do his shorting: namely, the latest members of the exponentially growing population of exchange-traded funds, managed by an outfit called ProShares.   Besides the relative rarity of funds that satisfy a bearish bias, our friend points out that, in contrast to an outright short sale, such ETFs offer the possibility of gaining long-term capital-gains treatment. They do so because the investor who acquires their shares goes long; he actually buys the ETFs, which, in turn, do the shorting of the stocks. The 29 such ETFs in the ProShares stable encompass a wide range of stock indexes and sectors.   They've been introduced over the past year, which obviously hasn't been an especially auspicious stretch to be negative on equities, as their performances by and large are melancholy reminders. But, as ventured at the top of this screed, markets do go down and sometimes sharply. And should that happen one of these months, the bears will come roaring out of the woods, even out of the woodwork.   At the very least, we thought it couldn't hurt to know about this particular permutation in ETFs, just in case.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Boeing, Jet Airways Bring New Look and Comfort to Paris
Story: LE BOURGET, France, June 16 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Displaying its new livery, Jet Airways' recently delivered Boeing (NYSE: BA) 777-300ER arrived Saturday in Le Bourget, France, ahead of Monday's opening of the 47th Paris Air Show.     The airplane's livery isn't the only change for India's largest private airline. Jet Airways' 777-300ER is fitted with a new interior, including newly created first class suites with premiere amenities.     Each of the first class suites offers nearly 26 square feet of usable space that can be closed off with sliding doors. The suites feature a 23-inch flat-screen monitor, storage areas that include a personal hanging wardrobe, dual credenzas and under-ottoman storage, and an 83-inch bed. With a business- jet style table, two can dine comfortably in the suite.     The twin-engine 777-300ER, one of 10 777s Jet Airways has ordered, is configured in three classes, including eight First Class suites, 30 Premiere seats and 274 Economy seats.     Jet Airways operates the 777-300ER on a Mumbai-London route. On Aug. 5, the 14-year-old airline will become the first private airline flying from India to the United States, operating the Boeing 777-300ER via Brussels -- its newly created European hub. The inaugural service will be Mumbai-Brussels-New York (Newark). Via Brussels, Jet Airways will launch future daily international services from Delhi, Chennai, Bangalore and Ahmedabad in India, to New York, Chicago, Toronto and Los Angeles. Daily Services to San Francisco via Shanghai are also planned.        Neg.  K64070    SOURCE  Boeing Co.       /CONTACT: Ken Mercer, Boeing Commercial Airplanes, +1-206-335-3120 or kenneth.b.mercer@boeing.com      /Web site: http://www.boeing.com/     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 15:10 ET (19:10 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Streetwise: Liquid Courage?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   It's futile to argue with the market, fruitful to inquire politely of it and listen.   The market's like the old dictatorial baseball umpire, who when asked by an impatient catcher whether a pitch was a ball or a strike, said, "It ain't nothing 'til I call it."   No piece of news is bullish or bearish until the market calls it. And so, last week's inflation numbers -- high on the headline, tame on the "core" -- were rendered as good enough excuses to rally.   It's fashionable on Wall Street to strike a maverick's pose and carp that "nobody" recognizes the real threat of inflation that's being papered-over by the supposed deceit of government data pushers. Yet the just-released Merrill Lynch fund-manager survey for June shows a net 47% of respondents saying core inflation will be higher in the next year, up from a net 11% in March.   So, looking for more inflation is anything but a contrarian stance. And if there's a buildup of inflationary danger, it's in the process of being absorbed by the market.   What stocks were suggesting is that they're not finished going up just yet, and have no interest in letting patient investors in. As soon as bond yields quit levitating on Tuesday, stocks fed off the rapidly accumulated investor anxiety of the prior week to rebound to new highs.   It confirms, for now, the silver-lining aspect of the bond selloff: The surge in 10-year Treasury yields above 5.25% was not mainly about inflation expectations, but rather a readjustment of growth prospects, observable in abiding strength in corporate-credit markets.   Perhaps it's a bit unsettling that the stock market has tried to discount the interest-rate move so rapidly. If that sharp but brief scare was all we're to get in the way of pullbacks, it will probably produce the market's version of the belligerent drunk's "liquid courage." Too much pain-deadening liquidity leads to picking battles with increasingly dangerous opponents, to painful ends.   We didn't get a true fear-propelled purge of stocks producing a washed-out state and a low-risk entry. Now we're back to a condition where stocks couldn't easily shrug off another upleg in rates or a drought-induced commodity shock or another rupture in the subprime-mortgage market.   Professional traders now have the tools to lunge at stock exposure quickly when the strong stuff gets flowing again, as exhibited by the massive surge in Standard & Poor's 500 exchange-traded-fund assets last week. Foreigners, never great market timers, have also been heavy buyers this year.   And yet, the public has no time for stocks, with traditional domestic stock funds losing still more assets. The absence of public excitement is probably the largest factor arguing against an imminent market top, despite the age of this bull market, the stretched earnings cycle and the unattractive valuation of the average stock.   Two consecutive pages of a fresh Ned Davis Research presentation packet neatly illustrate the opposing currents in the market. The first is a chart of the trailing price/earnings ratio of the median S&P 500 stock. Now above 20, it's at a level that implies subpar forward market returns.   Yet the next page shows the historically massive volume of equities being taken off the market by buyouts and buybacks over the past 12 quarters, a streak only about half as long as similar runs in the '80s and '90s.   The supply/demand setup and the tape's resiliency are the central reasons to give the market the benefit of the doubt. This, however, is no secret: Stocks have risen the past 13 Fridays in a row anticipating merger Monday, so the hunt for the increasingly price-insensitive marginal buyer is well entrenched in the Wall Street psyche.     Anyone seeking the perfect stock to satisfy the market's most intense fetishes could do worse than CB Richard Ellis (CBG). A big commercial real-estate broker, it sits where easy money flows into overpriced office buildings. And, it's a China/India story. And a busy acquirer.   The stock has more than tripled in the past two years, to a new all-time high of 39.40 at last quote, and fetches 18 times aggressive 2007 profit forecasts. It has outperformed real-estate investment trusts, as investors figure that CB Richard Ellis is a mere facilitator of extreme property values. The Street is unanimously in love with the stock -- nine analysts, nine Buys.   CEO Brett White addressed office values in the Wall Street Journal of June 6: "You still have this massive wall of liquidity looking for a home. Since 2001, commercial real estate as an asset class has been viewed very favorably relative to other asset classes."   There you have it again, "liquidity" as the one-word non-answer to "what's it worth." Only believers in the youth of the liquidity/hard-asset melt-up should buy this stock.   ---   e-mail: michael.santoli@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) The Trader: In The Mood For A Rousing Rally
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   The numbers did not look great. Retail sales improved 1.4% in May, but the rise was boosted by pricier gas. Consumer prices jumped 0.7% last month, the fastest pace in 20 months, though economists who acknowledged neither food nor gas saw a more benign uptick. Late payments and foreclosures on adjustable-rate mortgages rose to an all-time high. And oil futures pushing $68 a barrel suggests pump prices are headed higher.   But a stock market that lately has had more mood swings than a teenage girl tapped into its inner optimist last week and concluded the world just looks better. So what if Treasury yields near a five-year high point to rising borrowing costs that could slow profit growth? The important thing is that they've stopped climbing -- for now.   And so what if stocks aren't screamingly cheap? In a liquid world, and compared with real estate, bonds or metals, the stock market manages to look...somewhat safe and chaste. That honor may seem as dubious as being called the least-ugly contestant in a beauty pageant, but it was enough for a winning performance.   The stock market rebounded late last week from its early-June selloff, giving the Dow Jones Industrial Average its best three-day percentage-point gain since November 2004. The blue-chip benchmark even nudged briefly above its June 4 record close on Friday; it ended the week up 215, or 1.6%, to 13,639. The Standard & Poor's 500 has rallied in five of the past six sessions and added 25, or 1.7%, to 1533. The Nasdaq Composite Index increased 53, or 2.1%, to 2627, while the Russell 2000 index of small stocks climbed 13, or 1.5%, to 848.   Bulls, of course, relish the emphatic rebound. But market pullbacks increasingly have gotten shorter and shallower largely because money managers rush faithfully to buy every dip, a strategy that pays off...until it doesn't.   There are reasons for such optimism, not least of which is the bull run's unflinching recent track record. But there was also a growing sense that rising bond yields were egged on not by inflation but by global economic strength, and the hope that long-term rates might stabilize in a new range not quite high enough to thwart growth.   "The bond market is now priced more appropriately for rebounding economic activity, rising rates overseas and major foreign buyers diversifying away from dollar-denominated debt," says Jeffrey Kleintop, chief market strategist at LPL Financial. He sees the benchmark 10-year Treasury yield flitting between 4.75% and 5.25%.   Goldman Sachs strategist David Kostin recently counted 18 companies within the S&P 500 scheduled to be bought, representing some $232 billion in market value. All but two of these pending mergers are all-cash deals, and Kostin expects "a large portion of the cash received by investors will probably be redeployed to the current constituents of the S&P 500."   Higher borrowing costs take time to exact their toll on private-equity profits; until then, the prowl for targets is apt to continue putting a floor beneath stock prices.   Last week, shares of the energy market Nymex (ticker: NMX) jumped 13% on speculation it is mulling a merger. Dow Jones (DJ), the publisher of Barron's, ticked up Friday on reports that Pearson (PSO), publisher of the Financial Times, is rallying partners and contemplating a bid. And Penn National Gaming (PENN) agreed to be acquired by private-equity firms including Fortress Investment Group (FIG). But Fortress' own stock sagged 6% on worries over proposed legislation seeking to raise private-equity taxes.   Eventually, woes once brushed aside return to dog the market. The subprime fallout -- anyone remember the subprime fallout? -- was blamed last week by Bear Stearns (BSC) and Goldman Sachs (GS) for crimping second-quarter profits. The investment banks say subprime delinquencies haven't spread to other parts of the mortgage market, but caution that the worst isn't yet over.     It was another busy week for buyout and hedge-fund types. Oh, there were companies to be browsed, but that's what the staff is for. The serious buying was being done at Art Basel, the contemporary art fair where recurring red dots were this year's most prominent motif. And in London, the Russian art sale set another record as Konstantin Somov's "The Rainbow" fetched six times its top estimate.   Sotheby's shares (BID) climbed 5.8% on the week amid the continued art-buying clamor. At about 49, shares have rallied 42% since they were flagged in Barron's last fall ("Time to Bid!" Oct. 9, 2006), but they could climb higher still.   Summer was traditionally a lull in the art world, and the established trade was to sell Sotheby's at the height of the spring auctions, when the stock price peaked with the annual buzz. And, indeed, Sotheby's shares have pulled back since late April. But the throngs of billionaires from the world's assorted booms (oil, metals, private equity) have padded the art-world calendar, and expansive new lofts call for -- no, need! -- a Rothko, or a Pollock, or a Warhol...   So this week, the conspicuous consumers will flock to London for the Impressionists and contemporary art sales, and the recent track record suggests Sotheby's estimates may again be conservative. Record New York sales in May already bode well for the second-quarter earnings Sotheby's will report in early August, and Robbert van Batenburg, Louis Capital's head of research, expects earnings per share as high as $1.72 to beat consensus estimates of $1.34. The third quarter will kick off with the much-anticipated auction of Turner watercolors in London.   Among other catalysts: nearly $297 million in auction guarantees for which the mid-estimate sale prices are adding up to $329 million, and the profit boost from the sterling pound's 7% surge this year against the dollar.   A duopoly with privately held Christie's ensures strong pricing power, and both auction houses raised commissions this year by more than 10%. With Christie's snagging more market share in 2006's fall auctions, and Sotheby's regaining some of that this year, Sotheby's is "carrying considerable momentum into the back half of 2007" and faces easier year-over-year comparisons, notes Wedbush Morgan analyst Rommel Dionisio.   Sure, the art-auction business has famously high costs, and Sotheby's as a play on big spenders isn't a new idea. But recent skepticism works in the stock's favor. The billionaire Eli Broad last week pronounced Art Basel prices overvalued -- even as he reached for his first purchase of a Jeff Wall photograph. More than 11% of Sotheby's float is sold short, hardly a picture of runaway optimism seen at a stock peak.   Gasp-inducing prices for new art further increase demand for the kind of established works handled by Sotheby's and Christie's. Sotheby's June show, for example, includes a rare Monet ("Nympheas"), a Matisse ("Danseuse dans le fauteuil") and marquee names that quicken status-conscious pulses.   More important, record prices motivate "otherwise reluctant owners to bring their pieces to the market," Van Batenburg adds. "This emergence of more highly valued works of art not only generates higher revenue with higher margins, but also fuels the auction hype." The art boom won't last forever, but it can last a little longer (and typically crests only after the stock market does). Van Batenburg sees the stock pushing 66 by year end.     The boxing-equipment company Everlast (EVST) has a bantamweight market cap and a middleweight brand, but the fight over its future has all the drama of a heavyweight brawl.   In one corner is a management team that has nimbly steered shares up 560% over the past 19 months, but which delivered a surprise blow this month that floored some investors: a curiously hasty agreement to sell Everlast for a curiously low price. In the other corner is a growing group of short-changed stockholders who vow to fight the deal.   At stake is a New York company, founded in 1910, that makes an expanding line of sports apparel. But Everlast is most famous for the boxing gloves, punching bags and assorted gear worn by the likes of Muhammed Ali and Mike Tyson -- and by big-screen bruisers from Stallone to Swank.   The first uppercut landed June 1. Management announced an agreement to sell Everlast for $146 million, or $26.50 a share, to the Hidary Group, an investor outfit well-acquainted with the brand since it's one of its licensees. The all-cash deal offered investors a premium of 14.5% to the stock's May 31 closing price, or 30% above the average price in May. That may seem adequate were it not for the stock's upward trajectory, and the recent regularity with which Everlast raises forecasts and then beats them.   A 30-day "go shop" clause for Everlast to find a better bid looks insincere next to the $4.5 million breakup fee. Also curious was the June 4 agreement by CEO Seth Horowitz to vote the 19.2% of shares he controls in support of the Hidary offer --  even if a better offer emerges. It also did not escape investors' notice that Horowitz's employment contract was recently amended to remove limits on payments he might receive following a change of control.   The reply came swiftly. Aquamarine Capital, which holds a 2.3% stake, says it will vote against the low-ball offer. Since price is the decisive arbiter of cash bids, "why didn't the board of directors run an auction or actively take other measures to get the best possible price?" asks Jeff Lick, managing member of Galt Investments, which holds a 4% stake. Lick believes logical buyers including Nike (NKE), Adidas, Puma and Under Armour (UA) -- all hefty enough to flick away management if they bought the brand -- weren't contacted.   The unasked question among these firms' carefully lawyered missives: Why would management agree to an un-shopped lowball offer from an affiliate? Through a representative, Horowitz declined comment.   Meanwhile, Everlast shares have climbed above the bid and are trading at about 27.50.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Barron's Roundtable: Room To Run -4-
Story: A: Zulauf: The primary trend in equities remains bullish and intact. We are going through the business cycle and the financial-market cycle in steps, and the first step is usually disbelief after a recession. The second step is belief and growth, as the numbers come through in the corporate sector. Then we go into over-belief. The market probably is at the threshhold of over-belief. The fundamentals are fine. I do not see anything that should stop the world economy from expanding. We probably have another two to three years to go, because interest rates are still relatively low in most countries compared to growth rates.     Q: Does it trouble you that this seems to be the consensus view?   A: Not yet. So far the valuation case for equities remains intact. In Europe, corporate-bond yields are up to 5% or so. Large-cap equities -- and my thesis applies only to large caps -- trade at around 14 times trailing earnings. This gives you an earnings yield of 7%, versus a 5% bond yield, which provides a cushion for the stock market. The spread is a bit less in the U.S., but the economic framework is in favor of equities and not in favor of bonds.   In January I thought the market would probably have a decent year, although with a mild and a sharp correction. We had a mild and short correction in late spring, and likely will get a sharper one in the third quarter. But this is not going to be the end of the bull market. It will shake out a lot of investors, and then the market will go up again. Eventually, the difference between a 7% earnings yield and a 5% bond yield will be arbitraged away through all sorts of merger and acquisi-tion activity, corporate buybacks, private-equity deals and such.     Q: In other words, bond yields will rise?   A: Suddenly, it seems, everyone agrees the secular downtrend in yields is over, and cyclically and probably secularly yields are on the way up. So far the back-up in yields has not been driven by rising rates of inflation, because inflation in industrial and emerging economies is behaving well. In the later stages of the cycle, inflation will turn up, but it's the supply/demand situation that is driving bonds now. There is less demand. The corporate sector is seeing deteriorating free cash flow because of more capital expenditures. Private-equity companies are buying equities and selling bonds. Also, nations that are running large surpluses, like China and Russia, have announced they plan to buy more equities and other assets, not just government bonds. It's a step-by-step process.   It's possible that some of the big guys -- not only hedge funds and private-equity funds, but pension funds and insurance companies -- will lose their nerve as bond yields push higher, which could cause a snowball effect. Everybody is a short-term hedger these days. A steep selloff in stocks would be bad for those who have big long positions and are very leveraged. But it also offers opportunities to re-enter the market on the long side. You'll want to re-enter by buying the leaders and dominant themes. These days, it's all about the rise of China.     Q: That's a broad theme. How would you play China's rise?   A: Chinese shares may be in the early stages of a bubble. I'm not recommending them at 40 times earnings, but they could easily trade at 100 times earnings in 12 to 18 months. As an alternative, you could buy the Hong Kong H shares, which are half the price. These companies are registered in China, but trade in Hong Kong. I also like emerging markets, such as Korea and Brazil, which I would buy on a correction for a 12-month play. The Canadian market, which is largely a bet on natural resources, looks good too. It plays into the China theme. Capital-goods, industrial, materials and energy companies also will be core leaders in this cycle.   You can still buy the grains, particularly wheat. There has been quite a euphoria regarding corn, which suggests the wheat harvest may disappoint in quantity. If the weather turns bad, wheat could take off in a big way. On the negative side, look at acutely interest-rate sensitive companies and industries, such as real-estate companies in Spain and the U.K. The Spanish housing boom has been much, much bigger as a proportion of the Spanish economy than the boom in the U.S., and the excesses are much greater. Domestic Spanish banks also look risky.     Q: That stands to reason, if they have loaned to the real-estate companies.   A: In January, I recommended buying volatility through the VIX index, which still makes sense. If the market goes from belief to over-belief, volatility will increase. I'm also a big fan of natural gas at current prices, around $7.50 per million Btu. There have been production cuts in Canada, and about 10% of U.S. natural-gas fields have been depleted. The supply side is going to tighten up, and inventory levels are close to average. If the summer proves hot, demand could rise and the market could be tight, leading to a run in prices. Also, natural-gas facilities could sustain damage during the hurricane season. Natural gas still is trading well below the equivalent price of crude oil. It is a good value.     Q: How do European markets look to you, Felix?   A: It is interesting that American investors aren't very excited about Europe, except for those in the financial-services industry. In several European countries, you're seeing tax cuts, which is new and a positive development. The election of Nicolas Sarkozy as president of France is good for Europe because his agenda to reform France, and the French economy is supply-side driven. He's no Ronald Reagan, but at least it is a step in the right direction. Also, Europe is the cheapest major market. Large-cap companies are trading for only 14 times trailing earnings.     Sounds good. Thank you.     ARCHIE MacALLASTER     Q: Where does the market go from here, Archie?   MacAllaster: I see 2 1/2% inflation, 2 1/2% GDP growth and profits up maybe 6% or 7% on the year. The S&P 500 trades for just under 17 times earnings. It is a stockpicker's market -- the kind of market I like. When they're selling everything, it's no fun, and when they're buying everything, you can't make a difference. I thought the market would be flat this year, and it is up incredibly. By year end, who knows?     Q: At least you're honest.   A: If you take a longer-term view, stocks are not that expensive. A lot of bank stocks are cheap. I own four of the five largest, but I want to concentrate on Wells Fargo [WFC]. It is trading at around 35 and pays out $1.12 a share. The yield is 3.15%. It has shown consistent growth over many years. For the past 20 years Wells has averaged 14% annual growth in earnings, on 12% revenue growth. For the past five years earnings have increased by 21% a year, on average, and revenue by 11%. This year both will be up 10%-11%. The stock sells for 12 times our 2008 estimated earnings, compared with 16 or 17 times for the S&P. Wells Fargo will earn about $2.75 a share this year and $3 to $3.10 next. It is cheap, though it trades at a premium to most other large-bank stocks. But it deserves to. Under 12 times earnings, it's a buy. It consistently earns a 19%-22% return on equity, which is quite unusual.     Q: Wouldn't a back-up in interest rates pose problems?   A: No. Wells says it has 80 different businesses. If they get squeezed on interest rates a bit, other businesses will take up the slack. Besides, a spread is opening between yields on two-year and 10-year Treasuries that will help these banks. The company has raised its dividend for 19 years. They will probably raise it at least three cents this year, which is a gain of more than 10%. That gives you a yield of 3.5%. Wells Fargo is in the fastest-growing part of the country -- the West. My 12-month target price is 42.     Q: How about another recommendation?   A: I have recommended refinery stocks before, and they have worked out well. Valero Energy [VLO] is the biggest. It sells for 74 a share, and the dividend is 48 cents. It yields less than 1%. Valero is the largest refining company in the U.S., with daily capacity of more than three million barrels. This is roughly 30% of the total refining capacity in the U.S. and Canada. Spreads [between crude and refined oil prices] have been enormous and most people caution that this is a cyclical business, or at least it has been in the past. But it has become enormously expensive to build refineries, and none has been built in the U.S. for years. Valero will make a lot of money with these spreads.     Q: How wide are they, exactly?   A: They've been running as high as $20 a barrel, on average. Valero's spreads are high to begin with. About 65% of its feedstock is heavy crude, which is much more complex to refine, so that increases spreads plenty. My earnings estimates are higher than most analysts'. In 2007 they will earn between $9 and $9.50 a share. Next year they'll do between $10 and $11.50. The stock is good for 100 bucks within 12 months.   Additionally, Valero bought back about 5% of its stock last year and intends to buy in another 5% or possibly much more. The company is selling a refinery in the Midwest on which they have had three or four bids, and will end up cash-rich. They could even pay some kind of special dividend.   Lyondell Chemical [LYO], which I recommended in January, might be in play. A Russian-American billionaire, Leonard Blavatnik, bought options to purchase about 8% of the company through Merrill Lynch. He was one of three or four people who bid on General Electric's [GE] plastics business, which was sold to the Saudis. He bid $8 or $9 billion, and has enough money to make a bid for Lyondell.     Q: What could the company go for?   A: About 44 or 45 share. It currently trades for 37. If a deal doesn't happen and you wait a few more years, you'll get even more.     Thanks, Archie.     SCOTT BLACK     Q: What do you make of this market, Scott?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Northwest Airlines Begins Detroit-Brussels Nonstop Service
Story: Brussels is Northwest's sixth nonstop trans-Atlantic destination  EAGAN, Minn.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--June 16, 2007--   Northwest Airlines (NYSE:NWA), in cooperation with its joint venture partner KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, today continued the expansion of its European flight network with the start of daily nonstop service between Northwest's WorldGateway at Detroit hub and Brussels, Belgium. Flight 92 departed Detroit six minutes early at 5:39 p.m. on June 15 and arrived in Brussels at 7:38 a.m. local time today.     "Northwest's new nonstop Detroit-Brussels service will provide our customers throughout the Heartland of America with convenient service to one of the most popular destinations in Europe," said Laura Liu, Northwest vice president - international marketing and sales. "Brussels is the sixth nonstop European destination in Northwest's global route network and is an example of our commitment to add service to meet customer demand."     Northwest's Detroit-Brussels route is utilizing modified Boeing 757-200 aircraft that have been fitted with "winglets," or extensions of the aircraft wing to maximize fuel efficiency and increase range. Inside the aircraft, Northwest has made several improvements to provide trans-Atlantic customers with a comfortable travel experience.     The World Business Class (WBC) cabin is configured with 16 new seats in a two seat-aisle-two seat arrangement. Each WBC seat features five feet (1.5 meters) of personal space. The coach class cabin is equipped with 144 seats, configured in a three seat-aisle-three seat arrangement. The "pitch," or distance between rows, has been increased up to four inches (10 centimeters) to provide additional legroom and comfort.     In addition to nonstop Detroit-Brussels service, Northwest/KLM's trans-Atlantic expansion includes the addition of a second daily Detroit-Frankfurt frequency that began May 7, 2007, and nonstop Detroit-Dusseldorf service, which began June 5, 2007.     On July 1, 2007, Northwest is scheduled to begin daily nonstop Hartford, Conn.-Amsterdam service as well as add a fifth daily Detroit-Amsterdam frequency. Beginning July 15, 2007, Northwest/KLM will also offer a second daily Boston-Amsterdam flight.     All of Northwest's new flights are currently available for sale through the airline's Web site at www.nwa.com, Northwest Reservations Centers at 1-800-447-4747, or through travel agents.     Northwest Airlines is one of the world's largest airlines with hubs at Detroit, Minneapolis/St. Paul, Memphis, Tokyo and Amsterdam, and approximately 1,400 daily departures. Northwest is a member of SkyTeam, an airline alliance that offers customers one of the world's most extensive global networks. Northwest and its travel partners serve more than 900 cities in excess of 160 countries on six continents.        CONTACT: Northwest Airlines               Northwest Media Relations, 612-726-2331               www.nwa.com        SOURCE: Northwest Airlines  Copyright Business Wire 2007     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 09:35 ET (13:35 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(6/18) China's Next Export: Enthusiasm For US Stocks
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   What looks good to corporate China? U.S. stocks.   That's what the steward of the purse at one of China's largest insurers, Ping An Insurance, says. If he's right, that eventually could be very good news for U.S. equities, as Beijing moves to ease rules curbing capital outflows to slow the swift buildup of foreign currency that is putting upward pressure on the yuan.   To get a bigger return on its $1.3 trillion foreign-exchange pile, China is venturing into higher-risk investments, including a nearly 10% stake in private-equity group Blackstone. In coming weeks, Beijing is widely expected to let Chinese insurers boost the percentage of assets that they can invest outside the mainland, to 15% from 5% now, and to allow insurers to invest in shares in London and in New York.   Thus, John Pearce, Ping An's chief investment officer, is reviewing his global strategy. Pearce and Ping An's chief financial officer, Louis Chi Yan Cheung, won't speculate on the forthcoming changes, and it's too early to know what they'll do, given their positive outlook on China's economy and its appreciating currency. Still, Pearce says, "The U.S. is looking pretty good. The central bank has done a good job, and I have no reason to believe the U.S. won't do anything but have a soft landing."   Moreover, he observes, "the runup in U.S. shares was driven largely by small-caps. "The S&P 500 is only back to where it was five years ago, and earnings are about 45% higher." U.S. large-cap stocks, in his view, trade at "very reasonable" multiples and "are heavily leveraged to the global economy, which is expected to grow strongly. This will feed into earnings and underpin higher valuations."   Investing in higher-yielding vehicles is a boon to Ping An, which in recent years has had a tough time matching assets to liabilities as Chinese interest rates stayed low. This year, Chinese stocks have surged, helping offset meager returns from fixed-income investments.   At home, Ping An (ticker: 2318.Hong Kong) has been diversifying into infrastructure and private-equity plays. The coming changes should let the company, which had $65 billion in assets last year, invest up to $10 billion abroad. (Currently, non-Chinese equities can account for no more than 10% of the $1.75 billion in foreign-currency reserves that it raised in its 2004 initial public offering.)   Beijing is giving insurers greater latitude to battle ever-stiffer competition from foreign joint ventures. In March, Ping An won a license to manage assets in Hong Kong, which would help it to invest outside the Mainland for both domestic and overseas clients.   Its money-management business is growing briskly. In a recent test in the wealthy southern city of Shenzhen, just over the border from Hong Kong, the company collected $2 billion from wealthy individuals. The biggest potential client -- and one that Pearce and Cheung salivate over -- is Beijing itself, whose foreign-exchange pile is swollen by its need to buy dollars to maintain the yuan's peg to the U.S. currency.   Ping An, whose earnings jumped 88% in 2006 and which topped the list of high-returning stocks that Barron's profiled last year ("Winning Policies," March 13, 2006), is also sitting on $5 billion it raised by selling stock in Shanghai this year. (The insurer went public in Hong Kong in 2004.) "We are very eager to get some of this business," says Cheung.   It's no mystery why, after a year-long search, Ping An hired Pearce, who had been CEO of Australia's largest money manager. Australians have been leaders in investing abroad in infrastructure and other alternative plays. They simply have had to, as laws to encourage savings swamped their own capital markets with cash -- a situation similar to what China is experiencing as its trade gaps with many other nations balloon. Infrastructure investments can produce steady long-term cash flows and attractive yields, perfect for pension funds' long-term liabilities. Pearce, 44, pushed his former employer, Colonial First State, outside equities and into fixed-income and alternative investments, and struck alliances with outside investment boutiques.   Ping An has been investing in highways, power stations, structured loans and real estate -- grade-A office buildings and shopping malls, including the Citic Plaza arcade in Shenzhen. "Going forward, we have big well-known assets the state is looking to privatize," says Pearce. "Expect to see Ping An well-represented in those deals."   The insurer has invested heavily in the initial public offerings of domestic financial companies. Ping An owns A and H shares of Bank of China (3988.Hong Kong). A shares are the domestically listed shares open to Mainland investors and qualified foreign institutions, while H shares are listed in Hong Kong. And it has H shares of China Construction Bank (939.Hong Kong) and PetroChina (PTR), plus 4.9% of the A shares of Shanghai Pudong Development Bank (600000.China). Recently, it bought A shares of China Minsheng Banking (600016.China). And Ping An is enthusiastic about its own industry's prospects: It owns both A and H shares of China Life (LFC), the only domestic life insurer larger than Ping An.   "The banking sector is an excellent proxy for the Chinese economy," says Pearce. "The growing affluence of the population and ongoing deregulation will enable the Chinese banks to attain steady growth in the long run."   For all that some investors fret about Chinese stocks' 130% runup last year and 50% spurt this year, Pearce isn't alarmed. True, he acknowledges, "a market valuation of 30 times 2007 earnings certainly is not cheap." But, he notes, Chinese stocks are delivering earnings growth superior to that being generated by equities in the other BRIC (Brazil, Russia, India, China.) countries. "Among the BRICs, China is the only market where earnings revisions are still on an uptrend," says Pearce, who sees Corporate China's earnings jumping 24% this year.   "At this point, earnings can justify very high P/Es," he argues. "Most Chinese investors are still bullish about domestic prospects and renminbi appreciation. The market has had a great run, valuations are on the high side, but we're long-term investors, and these [gains] are underpinned by earnings." He notes that China's banking system has RMB36 trillion in deposits that needs "to find a home."   He's also optimistic about the outlook for emerging markets, particularly China's neighbors, even if the U.S. slides into recession, which he considers unlikely. Says Pearce: "The Chinese and Asian economies have a lot of internal growth momentum that will help cushion a U.S. economic shock. . . . Emerging markets offer far superior growth prospects than developed markets, supported by more efficient markets, massive liquidity and better governance, so risk factors have also declined. We obviously cannot rule out the possibility of another Asian Crisis, but the attraction of emerging markets certainly appears to be supported by good fundamentals at this stage."   And as Mainland investors broaden their horizons, that will only be good news for U.S. shares, emerging markets and Ping An itself.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Barron's Roundtable: Room To Run -8-
Story: A: Our analysts like Valero. It offers exposure to a favorable refining cycle. Refining capacity is constrained, and many projects that had been expected to come on stream have been delayed. Demand remains quite resilient. Our analyst concludes refining margins will stay strong, though there will be short-term volatility. Also, Valero is expected to buy back shares. Goldman's earnings estimates for this year are notably above the consensus. We think the company could do $12.25 a share, which implies a P/E of about six times earnings. For next year, our estimate is $12.50, and the P/E is 5.8. Consensus estimates for Valero are $9.50 for '07 and $7.91 for '08. If refining margins stay at current levels or move higher, estimates could be revised upward.     Q: What else do your colleagues like?   A: Hewlett-Packard [HPQ] is another margin-improvement story. Margins will improve in large part because of cost reductions, and earnings will grow in excess of revenue in the next few years. There will also be some revenue growth. HP is doing well in its core business, printers, and has gained share in software. It is also buying back stock. Our concerns are that the stock is widely owned, and has performed well in 2007. You have to take a longer view with regard to the company's ability to improve margins. Also, Hewlett-Packard benefits from international exposure, which exceeds 60% of their sales. Our earnings estimates are very close to consensus: The company could earn $2.78 a share in the fiscal year ending October, and has a P/E of 16.3. We estimate earnings of $3.15 in fiscal '08, and long-term earnings growth of 18%.   Another stock we like -- it's a new recommendation from Goldman Sachs -- is Pier 1 Imports [PIR], a turnaround situation. Pier 1 and its shareholders have gone through a difficult four years, and the stock is down 70%.     Q: Where does it trade these days?   A: It's around 8.60 a share. The company's margins have eroded significantly, as has its market share, but the possibility of a turnaround has improved. There is new management in place, and while Pier 1 will still have negative earnings for the next several quarters, it will become less cash-flow negative. The turnaround story has to do with cost reduction, in combination with improved spending on merchandising. We expect some reductions in overhead expenses, and some store closings. There is also room for improvement in Pier 1's supply chain. In recent years, the company lost market share as discounters came into their category and they were unable to distinguish themselves. New management understands what the issues are and will go after some bad merchandising decisions and unpopular marketing decisions.     Q: And your earnings estimates?   A: Goldman's estimates are well above the consensus. For this fiscal year ending February 2008, our earnings estimate is minus 68 cents. Ebitda will be negative this year but only slightly negative in fiscal '08. There is still the possibility of failure at Pier 1, but we feel increasingly comfortable the new management will be able to execute a turnaround.     Thank you, Abby.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
