Headline: Akzo Nobel In Final Stages Of Preparing Bid For ICI - Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Dutch chemicals giant Akzo Nobel (00913.AE) is in the final stages of drawing up a bid for ICI (ICI.LN), the Daily Telegraph reported Saturday, without naming sources.   The newspaper said that Akzo Nobel is understood to have mandated Morgan Stanley to advise it on a bid for ICI, maker of Dulux paint. According to the Telegraph, the investment bank is thought to be at an advanced stage of preparations for the bid, which could top GBP7 billion.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 07:20 ET (11:20 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(6/18) The Electronic Investor: Thomson, Reuters And You
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kathy Yakal   What's in the merger of information giants Thomson and Reuters for the little guy?   Although the two will operate separately until their deal becomes official, the combination has the potential to add more heft to Reuters' already formidable array of consumer offerings. For instance, it will have access to Thomson's trove of institutional-investment tools and real-time data feeds from which to draw new products, ideas and expertise.   A retail portal, Thomson Investor Network, fell flat some time ago, although it still offers earnings.com, which runs Webcasts and posts calendars of earnings calls and annual meetings.   But a spokesman says Reuters will continue to focus on individual investors: "We see no reason why this would change."   Reuters' offerings are enhanced by its global news-gathering force. But its investing portal offers much more than excellent business and economic reporting (Barron's parent, Dow Jones, competes with Reuters in several areas). It covers markets and industries and provides good portraits of individual stocks. Mutual- and exchange-traded-fund research and data come courtesy of Reuters' Lipper unit. You can catch up on commodities, bonds and currencies, and look for analyst research reports, too.   Reuters.com's screening tool isn't particularly friendly, but it's incredibly powerful; some prebuilt screens like Technology Bargains and Accelerating Growth are also available. And there are two good investor-oriented blogs on the site: the Deal Zone, which features Reuters reporters commenting on mergers and acquisitions and other corporate deals as well as dealmakers, and MediaFile, "where media and technology meet."   Reuters' Web presence goes far beyond its retail-investor portal. Lipper's mutual-fund Website (www.lipperweb.com) supplies news and commentary, analytical tools and mutual-fund information to the individual investor. The latter includes some access to research studies, a simple fund screener, Lipper's benchmark indexes, plus an overview of individual mutual funds that displays Lipper Leader Scorecards (a rating system for funds that takes into account total return, consistency of return, capital preservation, tax efficiency and expense).   HedgeWorld (www.hedgeworld.com) is also a part of the Reuters family. It's home to the Lipper TASS hedge-fund database, which offers more than 350 fields of information for 4,000-plus hedge funds and more than 300 commodity trading advisers (over 8,000 funds are covered).     Some content is free, including news stories and a daily newsletter and monthly magazine; articles covering hedge funds from more than 4,000 publications, through Lexis-Nexis; and tools for customizing your news delivery. You also get limited access to the Lipper TASS database Live Funds Module, and alerts when fund-performance numbers are updated.   Not surprisingly, $795 a year gets you more, including exclusive news not available at other subscriber levels, either daily or weekly, as well as charts and tables and access to archives (two-week trial subscription). Gold-Level members ($5,495 a year) get access to some features of the Lipper TASS database and premium search features.   Reuters has several professional and enterprise products. And its news and data appear on Websites such as Yahoo!Finance (finance.yahoo.com) and Google Finance (finance.google.com). Reuters also recently announced a kind of MySpace for market pros, a social-networking platform set up to foster an exchange of research, opinions and trading models around market activity, says the spokesman.   There's more, but suffice it to say that Reuters is on the job and that its pending link with Thomson ultimately should serve individual investors well.     New or Notable: Some of the old Gains-keeper folks have launched a new site, Geezeo (www.geezeo.com). Right now, it consists of Geezeo Mobile, which lets you view your balances at a bank or broker from your cellphone, and Geezeo Student. Geezeo has partnered with Simple Tuition (www.simpletuition.com) to offer an impressive network of potential lenders for consolidating or refinancing student loans . . . Money-Rates.com (www.money-rates.com) has a new look and additional content, but still excels at posting top rates for deposit-account rates . . . ID Vault helps you safeguard your online finances, using a hardware/software combo. Available online (www.idvault.com) for $29.99 after a $20 rebate (through July 31) and at major retailers. A mail-in rebate form is at the Website.   ---   e-mail: electronicinvestor@yahoo.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Research Reports: How Analysts -2-
Story: We believe that ROLL will continue to outperform other industrial stocks due to its unique business strategy. In our view, ROLL [which provides industrial, aerospace, and defense customers with design solutions] is unlike other industrial manufacturers because of high barriers to entry for the company's product niche. . . . We believe that there is more upside to ROLL's stock short term due to sales and EPS leverage to end aerospace super-cycle, defense, oil & gas, machinery and construction equipment . . . Shares of ROLL have done very well over the last year, with the stock up 75% in 2006 and 27% in 2007 year-to-date. The strength in the aerospace/defense cycle should result in sales and EPS growth. Specifically, ROLL's aerospace sales should benefit from a new Boeing supply contract . . . Defense sales should continue to expand due to transportation-related military spending and new products. Increasing our 2008 (March 2008) EPS estimates to $1.85 from our previous estimate of $1.80; increasing our 2009 EPS estimate to $2.25 from $2.20. Our 47 price target equates to a P/E of 20.9 times our FY09 EPS estimate.     Wind River Systems   -- WIND-NNM     Market Outperform   -- Price 10.40 on June 12   by JMP Securities     Maintaining Market Outperform rating and 13 price target, representing 25% upside from current levels. Wind River is a provider of embedded-system software and is well-positioned to capitalize on a number of trends, including a rise in complexity associated with device development and the widespread adoption of Linux. We [recently] accompanied a group of investors to Wind River's corporate headquarters in Alameda, Calif. In sum, we came away feeling quite comfortable with our investment rating and recommend investors accumulate shares in the name. Furthermore, we believe [the] proposed acquisition of TeleLogic AB by IBM suggests Wind River shares could fetch between $14 and $16. We are maintaining our FY08 EPS estimate of 27 cents, 3 cents below consensus, and our FY09 EPS estimate of 48 cents, 3 cents below current consensus. We estimate FY08 FCF/per share of 52 cents and maintain our FY09 FCF/per share estimate of 72 cents.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: EADS Astrium May Enter Space Tourism Market With Partners
Story: PARIS (Dow Jones)--EADS Astrium, a unit of European Aeronautic Defence & Space Co. NV (5730.FR), is examining whether to enter the emerging space tourism market though the development of a reusable space plane able to carry four passengers into low earth orbits, its top executive said on Friday.   Speaking at an EADS briefing before the Paris Air Show, EADS Astrium head Francois Auque said industrial partners are being sought for the project, which could cost EUR1 billion and would be funded only with private money. The small plane would fly 12 kilometers into space using conventional engines and then a rocket would be fired to propel it out to 100 kilometers from earth. Passengers would experience three minutes of zero gravity, Auque said.   "We believe there could be a market. We are finalizing the marketing of our technical concept," Auque said. He added that up to seven of the space planes and 20 rockets could be produced a year.   Auque spoke on Friday but his comments were embargoed until Saturday. A mock-up of the space plane will be shown at next week's Paris Air Show.     Company Web site: http://www.eads.com     -By Rod Stone, Dow Jones Newswires; 44-207-842-9295; rod.stone@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 08:00 ET (12:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Shenzhen Devt Bank Plans CNY16B Subordinated Bd, Hybrid Bd
Story: SHANGHAI (Dow Jones)--Shenzhen Development Bank Co. (000001.SZ) said Saturday it plans to issue up to CNY8 billion worth of subordinated bonds and CNY8 billion worth of hybrid bonds to improve its capital adequacy ratio.   The subordinated bond issue will have a maturity of between five years and 15 years and the maturity of the planned hybrid bonds will be 15 years or longer, the lender said in a statement.   The bank's board has approved the bond issuance plans, which will be discussed for shareholders' approval July 20, it said.   In a separate statement, the bank said its yuan-denominated A shares will resume trading Wednesday.   Shenzhen Development Bank's A shares closed at CNY28.69  May 31, and were suspended from trading.   Newbridge Capital, a unit of Texas Pacific Group, bought a 17.89% stake in the Chinese bank in late 2004. Newbridge Capital is now the largest shareholder of the bank.   In late 2005, U.S. financial services and industrial firm General Electric Co. (GE) agreed to buy a 7% stake in Shenzhen Development Bank for $100 million. The deal is still pending approval by regulators.   (Zheng Jin contributed to this story, Dow Jones Newswires; 8621 6120-1200; jin.zheng@dowjones.com)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:16 ET (04:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Meet The (Not-So-)Poor Man's Warren Buffett
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   For all of Berkshire Hathaway's success under Warren Buffett's leadership of the past four decades, very few companies have pursued a similar strategy.   Alleghany, a low-profile New York company, may be the closest thing to a small-scale Berkshire in the public market. Like Berkshire, Alleghany (ticker: Y) focuses on insurance and equity investments. Like Berkshire (BRK-A), Alleghany has a great balance sheet with considerable excess capital. Like Berkshire, Alleghany has a conservative CEO and board that primarily measure their performance the old way -- by growth in shareholder equity, or book value. Like Berkshire, Alleghany communicates little with Wall Street. Like Berkshire, Alleghany has a strong long-term record, delivering a 15% annualized return since 1967, five percentage points better than the S&P 500 index, although shy of Berkshire's great 21%-plus yearly gain under Buffett.   Also like Berkshire Hathaway, Alleghany refuses to split its shares, resulting in one of the highest stock prices on the Big Board. At $362 Friday, the company's market value was $3 billion, versus Berkshire's $168 billion. (Berkshire's A shares fetch almost $110,000 apiece.)   Alleghany's admirers like its management, led by Chief Executive Weston Hicks. They favor its mix of insurance businesses and consider its stock inexpensive, trading at 1.3 times its March 31 book value of $271 a share. "The company is stocked with cash, and you have a smart guy at the helm," says Jeffrey Bronchick, chief investment officer at Reed Conner & Birdwell, a Los Angeles investment manager that holds about 3% of the outstanding shares. "Alleghany is one of those sleepers. The downside is boredom -- a 10% return each year --  and the upside is 50% over the next two or three years," he adds.   Alleghany trades for a lower valuation than Berkshire, which commands 1.5 times book. Berkshire's advantage is a better set of businesses. Berkshire's disadvantage is sheer size. Buffett must invest in billion-dollar chunks, while Alleghany has a much wider array of opportunities, since it can move the needle with a $100 million investment.   Alleghany can't match Berkshire's investment record, but it has done well. Its largest equity holding is Burlington Northern (BNI), the railroad company. Berkshire caused a stir when it disclosed two months ago that it had purchased $3 billion of Burlington shares. Alleghany beat Berkshire to the stock by a decade, paying just $12 a share for its five million shares, versus Friday's price of $90. In fact, Burlington accounts for half of Alleghany's $1 billion equity portfolio. Most of the rest of its holdings are energy shares such as Chevron (CVX) and ConocoPhillips (COP), which are up an average of 50% since Alleghany bought them in 2005.   The Burlington investment was made by John Burns, Hicks' predecessor, and the energy investments by Hicks, a 50-year-old former insurance analyst who joined Alleghany in 2002 after a one-year stint as chief financial officer at the insurer Chubb.   Hicks wouldn't talk with Barron's, reflecting Alleghany's penchant for minimal media contact. Investors who want to understand Alleghany must do their own work because no analysts cover it. The company doesn't even hold quarterly conference calls or investor meetings.   In its annual report, Alleghany makes clear that "conservatism dominates our management philosophy," adding that its goal is "double-digit" annual growth in book value "without employing excessive amounts of financial leverage or taking undue amounts of operating risk."   Bronchick credits Hicks with "moving Alleghany into the 21st century." Since his arrival, Hicks has transformed a company that was little more than a pile of cash into a mini insurance conglomerate. Alleghany's largest insurance unit is RSUI Group, a property and casualty specialist that has produced $240 million of underwriting profits since its purchase in 2003. Alleghany also owns 55% of Darwin Professional Underwriters (DR), an insurer that was taken public last year after Alleghany formed it in 2002 by financing a well-regarded group of insurance executives led by Stephen Sills. The Darwin stake is now worth $220 million. In 2006, Alleghany paid $120 million for 33% of Homesite Group, a home insurer. In April, it purchased Employers Direct, a California-based specialist in workers' compensation, for $195 million.   Alleghany's insurance units made $28 a share in 2006, accounting for the bulk of the company's $30-a-share in full-year earnings. Last year marked a big improvement over 2005, when Alleghany lost $5 a share from insurance operations, largely due to a $313 million hit from Hurricane Katrina and other storms.   In the first quarter, Alleghany earned $8.28 a share from insurance. Those profits probably can't be sustained through the year because there were minimal catastrophe losses in the period. Hurricanes usually are most prevalent in the third quarter. Still, it's not unreasonable to project that the insurance units can earn $25 a share annually. If the equity portfolio returns 12% yearly, that would contribute another $10 a share each year to book value, helping the company hit its goal of double-digit growth in book.   The chief risks with Alleghany are the potential for large insurance losses, although Alleghany has substantially trimmed its catastrophe exposure since Katrina; a big drop in the stock market, and a sharp rise in rates, which would hurt its $2.8 billion bond portfolio. Another danger: The property and casualty insurance cycle may be peaking, threatening underwriting profits.   The company sits on about $1 billion -- or $125 a share -- of excess capital. Alleghany shares, meanwhile, are only about half as volatile as the S&P 500 index. Like Berkshire, the company pays no cash dividend, even though it could easily afford one.   Looking ahead to the end of the current quarter, Alleghany's book value could top $285 a share, based on insurance earnings and a rally in Burlington Northern and oil shares. That suggests that Alleghany now trades below 1.3 times forward book value.   That book value, moreover, probably is understated because the company carries its Darwin stake, plus real estate it owns in the Sacramento area, at below-market-value prices. Adjusted for this, the June 30 book value could be $300. This suggests that Alleghany stock is priced reasonably despite its high absolute price.   Hicks is only Alleghany's third CEO in the past 40 years. His predecessor, Burns, ran the company from 1992 to 2004. The chief executive before Burns was Fred Kirby, who took the helm when his father, Allan Kirby, had a stroke in 1967.   Alleghany dates to 1929, when it assembled a group of railroads -- just before the stock-market crash and the Depression. Alleghany managed to survive, making a shrewd purchase of Investors Diversified Services in the 1940s. That business, known as IDS, eventually was sold at a huge profit to American Express in 1984.   Fred Kirby, now 87, retired as chairman at the end of 2006. He owns 12% of Alleghany. The Kirbys, including Fred's brother, Allan, 75, together control about a third of the company's thinly traded shares. Alleghany likes its independence, but there's a chance of some future corporate transaction, given the key shareholders' ages.   Reed Connor's Bronchick argues that Alleghany doesn't get full credit for its insurance operations, notably RSUI, which he compares to such well-regarded outfits as Markel (MKL) and RLI (RLI), which command as much as twice book value.   Hicks isn't likely to be rash about investing Alleghany's $1 billion of excess capital. The company has favored insurance investments because it knows the field and doesn't face competition there from insatiable private-equity buyers, who can't use leverage as easily in insurance.   Investors now are paying only a modest price for the company Hicks has energized. If Alleghany's book value can expand at a double-digit rate in the next few years, the stock could rise 50% by 2010 -- not bad for a low-risk investment.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:10 ET (04:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) The Striking Price: A Strategy Built For Bulls
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   Opportunity often resides between contradiction and fear.   As bond yields rise and the volatility of many equity options floats higher in anticipation that stocks may go lower, a paradoxical trade is emerging, just as the second-quarter earnings season begins. Goldman Sachs' wily options strategists recommend selling put options to express a bullish view on mega-cap stocks, even as some investors fret that stocks will slip during the lazy days of summer.   The rationale for this seemingly contrarian trade is a market call by Goldman's portfolio strategist, who thinks stocks may advance into the summer because investor expectations are too conservative, especially for big companies. Sound familiar? First-quarter profits also were expected to be lackluster. But they beat expectations, helping to propel stocks to new highs.   Many stocks have recovered nicely since the recent 3% decline in the S&P 500, yet Goldman's options strategists, Maria Grant and John Marshall, have identified 15 mega-caps with elevated options prices, and strong fundamentals that are worth betting on. After screening their universe of liquid options -- about 350 names -- they found that the implied volatility of stocks with market capitalizations above $40 billion were significantly higher than that of smaller issues. These stocks' implied volatility -- essentially, price -- had risen, on average, 5.1% in the previous week, versus 2.7% for smaller stocks. Implied volatility also is higher for mega-caps than it is elsewhere in the market.   To benefit from these discrepancies, the strategists recommend selling three-month puts on Target (TGT), AT&T (T), PepsiCo (PEP), Coca-Cola (KO), Comcast (CMCSA), Oracle (ORCL), Sears (S), IBM (IBM), Wells Fargo (WFC), Merrill Lynch (MER), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Morgan Stanley (MS), Amgen (AMGN), General Electric (GE), and Disney (DIS).   To qualify for the list, stocks had to be rated Buy by Goldman's equity analysts, have three-month volatility among the most expensive of the past year and boast a market value above $40 billion. Target's three-month options volatility, for example, is at its highest level of the year, and AT&T, Pepsi and Coca-Cola options aren't far behind.   Goldman's portfolio strategist, David Kostin, believes second- quarter consensus earnings estimates are too low. He views large-caps as more attractive than small-caps, in part because big stocks have about double the exposure to fast-growing international markets, and this helped them report better-than-expected first-quarter net. Moreover, large-caps are less sensitive to interest rates and widening credit spreads, owing to their generally well-managed balanced sheets. In addition, based on measures such as price-to-earnings and price-to-book ratios, large-caps are at the bottom of their 20-year average, and hedge funds "have recently began to shift" into large- and mid-cap stocks and away from small-caps.   If the trades work, investors will be in for an end of summer treat. If not, they'll get a chance to own some good stocks, and that's not bad either.   ---   E-mail: steven.sears@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: :ASDA Declares Price War With £250m Of Rollbacks
Story: Research Shows Average Family's Disposable Income is £146   ASDA fired the first salvo in a £250m supermarket price war today ( 16 June), lowering 10,000 prices across food, George and general merchandise to celebrate winning the Grocer's lowest price supermarket award for the tenth year running.   The move is especially pertinent after ASDA research, released for the first time today, shows that the average British family has only £146 per month of disposable income after they've paid all the bills*.   The price move builds on ASDA's consumer championing history following a decade of winning Britain's lowest price supermarket award.  The average ASDA shopper's inflation busting basket is now 17% lower in real terms than in 1997* as a result of ten years of price cuts.   'We have a ten year history of fighting to keep prices low for consumers. We are declaring a supermarket price war today. Our research shows how little the average family has left once they've covered their living expense which makes me even more committed to delivering Britain's lowest basket of groceries.   "Rip-off Britain, where other retailers con their customers, is alive and well and we're determined to put a stop to it once and for all.  Over the next year we're going to expose businesses that prey on customers, forcing them to pay through the nose for goods and services while they pocket massive margins," added Andy.   ASDA has a longstanding history of championing the consumer and undercutting standard industry prices in order to pass savings on to customers.     In the past the company played a pivotal role in challenging the Net Book Price Agreement meaning that retailers were no longer forced to sell books at recommended retail prices and also put an end to the over the counter medicine rip-off.   More recently it challenged greedy soccer bosses and sports stores over extortionate football strips and championed the parent's right to choose where they buy their kid's school uniform.   Amongst other things, today ASDA doesn't charge a premium for higher factor suncreams, is now able to offer the latest book releases at hugely discounted prices and guarantees that products in its healthy eating range are never more expensive than the standard own brand equivalents.   The supermarket has also led the way with unbeatable prices offering products such as a complete school uniform for less than £10, a £19 men's suit, £60 wedding dresses and DVD players for just £9, as well as delivering Britain's lowest priced petrol*.   For further information please contact Ed Watson: 0113 241 7829  Notes to editors :   Outgoing       Per Month       Source / Assumed  Take Home Pay   £1588   Based on 28k household pre tax annual income  Mortgage        £510    Based on 75k mortgage with 20 years at 5.5%  Car Loan        £176    5000 spread over 3 years  Insurances      £60     Estimate based on 1.4 Astra, 100k house, 50k life  Food (inc alcohol)      £304    Market divided by # households. Source: TNS  Council Tax     £92     Office of national statistics January 2007  Petrol  £112    12000 miles per year at 87ppl and 33mpg  Utilities       £92     Source: The Scotsman, £692 gas, £363 electric, £131 TV  Clothing        £96     Market divided by # households @ 90%  Truly Disposable Monthly Income £146   Asda economic boffins compared the price of 26 every day groceries in 1997 and 2007.  The price in 1997 was £29.39, by 2007 this had dropped to £29.10.   However if you apply inflation to the 1997 basket it should actually cost £35.28 today, a difference of 17.5%. Headline: Barron's(6/18) European Trader: What HSBC Really Needs
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Arindam Nag   HSBC's weak share-price performance over the past year is prompting calls to break up the group. But the immediate problems lie in the boardroom, rather than in geographic diversification.   HSBC has been battered by the U.S. subprime-mortgage mess. But the banking concern, whose American depositary shares trade on the Big Board under the ticker HBC, looks better when judged over a longer span. Its shares have outpaced those of Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS.U.K.), Citigroup (C) and Bank of America (BAC), especially since 2004, when the Fed started raising interest rates. (The ADSs were trading early Friday around 92.50 -- about midway between their 52-week high and low.)   The longer view shows that HSBC shares fare better than their peers when systemic risks -- macro fundamentals  -- go against the banking industry. Reason: The company's earnings streams come from various global regions and are less correlated with one another than are the sources of some other big banks' profits.   Standard Chartered (STAN.U.K.) has outperformed HSBC because most of its earnings come from emerging markets. But StanChart is also riskier; its 52-week beta -- a measure of how much more it rises or falls when the overall market moves -- is 1.4, nearly three times that of HSBC.   The return-per-unit-risk advantage would be lost if HSBC were broken up. HSBC Asia would alone be riskier than HSBC as a whole. This also would be evident in HSBC's cost of capital and ability to act as counterparty on derivative transactions. A breakup would result in similar disadvantages for the bank's other parts.   Two additional risks would arise if HSBC's Asia business were spun off. First, the Asian growth story may be overheating and is due for a pause, especially in China, where the government is desperate to tighten.   Also, Asian economies are increasingly integrating. Bilateral trade between India and China, for instance, is up to $18 billion today from $2 billion six years ago and is expected to jump to $100 billion by 2015. That means the economic cycles of these two Asian growth engines will become increasingly correlated.   For a standalone HSBC Asia, that would be good news during boom times, but highly risky during a downturn.   What HSBC needs isn't a breakup, but rather a tighter hold over its global assets. More skill at transferring best practices, technologies, products from one region to another. It hasn't been able to integrate acquisitions quickly.   Investors should urge HSBC to fix its board of directors, which lacks diversity. It needs a new chairman, one who's not a former HSBC CEO.   Undoing past mistakes will take longer. Most of its independent board members are from the U.K. More balance, with greater understanding of HSBC's major markets, would be preferable.   Non-executive directors should meet more often without management present. HSBC's non-exec directors met only twice last year. Their counterparts at Citi met seven times. Improving corporate governance would add shareholder value, as well.   ---   Arindam Nag is a contributor to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                        DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES    Region/  Country     DJ Global          DJ Global           DJ Global     Point      Indexes,           Indexes,            Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg. Headline: R20 Eyes Sainsbury Property Venture -FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--R20, the investment vehicle owned by property investor Robert Tchenguiz, is preparing a new proposal to unlock the value of J Sainsbury's (SBRY.LN) property portfolio and return a substantial amount of cash to the supermarket group's shareholders, the Financial Times reported Saturday.   It comes as Delta Two, the investment group backed by the Qatari prime minister, increased its grip on Sainsbury - paying GBP732 million, before the market opened Friday, to take its stake to 25%.   The newspapers said Tchenguiz's vehicle wants to create a 50-50 joint venture with the supermarket group on its property assets, which it values at up to GBP10 billion.   According to the FT, this would allow Sainsbury to raise about GBP7 billion net of existing debt, which could be returned to shareholders at 420 pence a share. It would also leave extra cash to redevelop some of the property portfolio.   Tchenguiz has a declared stake in Sainsbury of about 5%, but the FT said his actual holding, including derivatives, is near 10%.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 06:36 ET (10:36 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Fund Of Information: Growth And Value Power A Fund's Big Gains
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   Rajiv Jain, who took over the Phoenix Foreign Opportunities fund in early 2002, has consistently beaten most of his peers.   His secret?   Getting enough picks right to more than offset his mistakes, as any successful active money manager must do. Among other things working against him were his light exposure to energy, and his relatively low exposure to China, which Jain maintains is overvalued compared with other world markets. He also avoids corporate restructurings and cyclical companies.   But clearly, he's gotten a lot right. His portfolio (ticker: JVIAX) has a five-year annual return of 20.3%, putting it in the top 6% of Morningstar's foreign large-blend category. Lipper points out that the fund has outperformed most of its peers while having just an average risk profile, as measured by standard deviation. So relative to rivals, Jain isn't betting the ranch to get these results.   Although light on China, Jain does have a big stake in Indian companies, which account for about 8% of the portfolio, including HDFC Bank (HDB).   His long-term winners include food retailer Tesco (TSCDY), British American Tobacco (BTI) and Anglo Irish Bank (AGIBY).   They're all part of his growth-at-a-reasonable price bent. "Every company we own should be a growing enterprise," explains Jain. "Having said that, you don't want to pay for the growth."   Jain is comfortable holding a stock for years. The load fund, whose annual expense ratio is 1.37%, has assets of just over $1 billion.   It's a concentrated portfolio. The top 10 holdings account for about 40% of the fund, although he doesn't like to let individual stocks exceed 5%.   Compared with the global index MSCI EAFE, Phoenix Foreign Opportunities is underweight Japan. Elsewhere, it has a relative overweighting in the United Kingdom, whose banking sector Jain believes is undervalued. His holdings there include the Royal Bank of Scotland (RBSPY).   Another country where he sees opportunity is Spain. Holdings there include Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBV), which also has extensive operations in Latin America, mostly Mexico.   The fund's strong performance has prompted fast asset growth, which can turn into a problem because the investing universe diminishes. That's a key challenge for Jain, and shareholders should monitor it. Jain, however, maintains that nearly all of the best new ideas are in larger-cap stocks, with market capitalizations of at least $8 billion.     Daniel Wiener isn't among those fretting over the effects of higher bond yields. The editor of the Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors points out that there have been three occasions since the early 1990s when the yield on the 10-year Treasury rose sharply. Each time, he notes, real gross domestic product continued to grow, and small- and large-cap stocks mostly continued to make gains, although bond mutual funds took a big hit. Rates above 5% (the 10-year Treasury topped 5.2% last week) will increase borrowing costs, Wiener says, "but this is not going to derail an economy" that's "slowing but still growing."   ---   E-mail: lawrence.strauss@barrons.com   ---             Scoreboard         Natural Resources Lead the Way     -- U.S. diversified stock funds rose an average 1.93% in the week ended Thursday, says Lipper, Reuter's fund-tracking arm. The broad market was up 2.20% in that span. Natural-resources funds fared best, rising 4.12%. Headline: Barron's(6/18) Barron's Roundtable: Room To Run -3-
Story: A: No one knows. No one knew that March 10, 2000, would be the end of the dot-com bubble. It could be a month from now. It could be today! I would be surprised if it doesn't happen by the time January rolls around. We have real, serious problems. The dollar is deteriorating against almost all currencies. Bond yields are backing up big-time, causing all sorts of ripple effects. Potential leveraged buyouts might not get done. Huge pyramids of leverage could start to implode. The back-up in rates comes at a time when the U.S. consumer has finally had it. Month after month retail sales disappoint. In April, 75% of retailers missed their same-store-sales targets. The consumer, facing hundreds of billions of dollars of mortgage-rate resets, now gets hit with rising rates. Wrong timing. Housing prices are falling nationwide. Mortgage-equity withdrawals have collapsed. In May, foreclosures were up 90% year over year. Gasoline prices are up 30% from the first quarter. We are looking at potentially the greatest food-price inflation in 30 years. Higher health-insurance costs. Lower benefits. You can't have a worse scenario for the consumer.     Q: At least people are employed.   A: The government's employment numbers are bogus. They reported a gain of about 230,000 jobs in the past two months, but 520,000 of them came from a computer model -- the birth/death model. If we had real numbers we would know we are already in a recession.     Q: Are you out of the market completely?   A: In January, I had lots of cash; gold and silver, which have done well, and Canadian bonds, which have been fantastic. I also had some gold and silver stocks. I am so nervous that I sold those. I intend to repurchase them when it looks like the Fed will be forced to come to the rescue. Right now I'm 97% in U.S. Treasuries, Canadian bonds and gold and silver. I'm 3% short against the stock market, almost entirely through put options. Oh, and I have one millionth of 1% in EMC [EMC] calls.     Q: Earlier this year, you recommended shorting Apple and Research In Motion, both of which have rallied sharply. What should investors do with those stocks now?   A: I short stocks by buying puts because shorting can be so dangerous, as these examples illustrate. Also, these positions are just a tiny portion of my portfolio. In Apple's case [AAPL], revenue growth continued to decelerate in the latest quarter, and iPod sales were down. But the bottom line was up sharply because of a one-time collapse in memory prices. They guided revenue estimates lower. What happened? The stock went up on hopes for the iPhone. This is a product no one has tried. The cost is huge. It runs on the slowest network there is. The keyboard is unusable for e-mail. And these are the flaws we know about. New investors should wait until the iPhone comes out and then short the stock, again using puts.   As for Research In Motion [RIMM], both companies can't win on the iPhone's launch. RIM has focused on the business market, but now is targeting consumers, which is bad. I have long thought RIM could be the next Palm, which was a hot stock and hot product in the dot-com era. Every executive and every housewife in Greenwich had to have a Palm Pilot. Not any more. RIM has less than 1% of the 1 billion-unit handset market. It is up against huge competition. If the iPhone is a hit, RIM is in trouble. Maybe both will be losers. Theoretically, my short position is down 17% since January, but I plan to add to it via puts because the valuation makes no sense. You're paying $31 billion for a company with a 1% market share.     Q: Have you any other advice?   A: Buy two-year Treasury notes. It sounds boring, but cash is not trash. At times like this, you want to have cash because you'll be able to buy amid the rubble. The two-year note yields 5.1%, which is pretty darned good.   On the negative sid, I'm shorting NetLogic Microsystems [NETL], again through puts. NetLogic is a semiconductor company that provides components mostly to the network-equipment market. Cisco Systems [CSCO] generated two-thirds of their revenue in the latest quarter. A few weeks ago Cisco, IBM [IBM], EMC and Sun Microsystems [SUNW] all said their U.S. enterprise revenue was weakening. Cisco warned in May of lower growth. But that may be the least of NetLogic's problems.     Q: What else could go wrong?   A: New competitors are moving in, including Integrated Device Technology [IDTI] and Renesas, a Japanese semiconductor company. They are undercutting NetLogic on price and Cisco is diversifying its supplier base. Worst of all, Cisco recently bought SpansLogic, a direct competitor to NetLogic. NetLogic trades for 30. It is selling for 6.5 times sales and 30 times this year's estimated earnings. Sales growth in the next two quarters is expected to be zero. Earnings per share for the next two quarters are expected to be down 19% and 15%.     Q: That sounds grim.   A: There is a lot of pressure on me and others to be bullish, but I can't. In 2002 I got out of all of my puts -- my shorts -- and went long. But I knew that posture ultimately couldn't be sustained.   Thank you, Fred.   ART SAMBERG     Q: Do the market's prospects still impress you?   A: Samberg: The market's multiple has shrunk two years in a row. You might not like everything you see out there, but people are employed and things move forward. Corporate profits are growing at a 10% annual rate and the market is not up 10% yet. The other driver for stocks is the wad of money in private-equity hands. It is absurd, but I have learned one thing in life: It is very important to recognize absurdity, but also very stupid to get in the way of it. I don't see the private-equity boom abating. If corporate profitability in the U.S. is OK, the rest of the world is continuing to grow and private-equity deals are driving stock action in the U.S., the market could be up about 10%. this year.     Q: It's up more than 5% already.   A: The S&P 500 is up about 7%, or 15% on an annualized basis. That's too much, so I'm sure we'll get hit over the head soon. Adjustable-rate mortgages really started resetting in May and the resets peak around January, so housing-market troubles could impact the stock market in the second half. There will be another consumer scare between here and the end of the year. We'll get some kind of a correction. But the big drivers are corporate profitability and all the money sloshing around. Not much has changed since January.     Q: One thing has changed: Most of your January picks are higher, including the for-profit-college stocks. Do you still like them?   A: Hopefully, the group's earnings will start coming through. Apollo Group [APOL], which is around 48, could double from here. My cotton pick hasn't worked as well, and I'd like to reemphasize it. I expected the Chinese to swoop in and buy up cotton, but I neglected to mention one thing in January: U.S. inventories were high at more than 10 million bales. Inventories get depleted or added to based on Chinese demand and the timing of China's orders, and for several months China didn't place many orders. Inventories are finally beginning to drop.     Q: So China finally has made its move?   A: I think so. When the data comes in on this year's cotton crop, the amount that comes to market could be even less than expected. There is dry weather in Georgia and Texas, and according to the data 20% less cotton was planted this year. All the elements of this trade are still in place.   I also recommended two Brazilian home builders in January -- Gafisa [GFSA3.Brazil] and Brascan Residential Properties [BISA3.Brazil] -- and the outlook for both is still terrific. The Selic, Brazil's lending rate, is down since the beginning of the year to 12%. Land prices are up 40% year over year. Gafisa is flat but Brascan is down about 20%, which is silly. It's due to technical factors. About seven other developers were slated to come to market, and investors got scared about an excess supply of home-building stocks. In the end the IPOs didn't happen, but Brascan sold off because of the expected overhang. It is much more of a local stock than Gafisa, which is partly owned by Sam Zell. The story for both is just as strong as it was in January, if not stronger. I'm still recommending both, but with the emphasis on Brascan.     Q: How about a new name?   A: Research In Motion is a new old name, which I have recommended before. As I see it, RIM sells an enterprise solution, not a consumer product. To view it as a consumer product is to miss the annuity stream and value of the business. Last year the company introduced the BlackBerry Pearl, a hand-held device aimed at the consumer market. It didn't sell as well as expected. Now it has entered a new enterprise cycle and introduced the 8800 and Curve 8300, which looks like a phenomenal device. It is going to sell like hot cakes. We think RIM may be ready to launch a Japanese-language version of the product in the fall, with NTT DoCoMo. I don't really care what Apple's iPhone looks like, because that's not what RIM is about. Someday this company shouldn't even make handsets, but concentrate solely on enterprise-software solutions. Someday it will also be part of another company.     Q: RIM trades for 170. How much higher can it go?   A: In the fiscal year ending February 2009, which is mostly calendar '08, the company could earn as much as $6.50 a share and the stock could sell for more than 30 times earnings. It is a $200-plus stock.     Q: What is your view of the tech sector in general?   A: It continues to be boring. Wireless telephony interests me. Companies in the 3G area are doing well. I also recommended Baidu.com [BIDU], the Chinese Internet search engine, in January. It sold off at the beginning of the year and then rebounded, though it isn't up hugely. Speculation in the Chinese A-shares market isn't happening with Baidu, which has more appeal to Western institutional investors. The fundamentals are great.     Thanks, Art.     FELIX ZULAUF     Q: You were fairly upbeat in January, Felix. Are you still?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Follow-Up: Mining Shares May Have Peaked
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   Seemingly insatiable demand for base and precious metals, fueled in part by China's growth, has helped give a powerful lift to mining-company shares. But those shares now look fully valued.   Barron's has been a fan of the sector for the past year ("Prospecting for Bargains," June 19, 2006), based chiefly on the outlook for commodities prices. That story focused on Brazil's Companhia Vale Do Rio Doce, known as CVRD (ticker: RIO) and Anglo-Australian Rio Tinto (RTP). CVRD's American depositary receipts have more than doubled since, to 46.88 from 21. Rio Tinto's stock is up 53%, to around 308.   Much of the advance came from sky-high commodity prices. But the stocks also have gotten help in recent months from buyout speculation. Investors would do well to treat that speculation with caution. In fact, it's hard to make a case there's much upside left in the pair.   Like most companies in the metals sector, CVRD and Rio Tinto are considered well run, which suggests there would be little room for a buyer to make operating improvements. Any sale prices would likely be high, especially in view of the high level of commodities prices. It's hardly an opportune environment for takeovers, says Damien Hackett, global head of mining research at the brokerage Canaccord Adams.   In general, he thinks the shares are fully valued. Most stocks in the sector, he says, are trading at nine or 10 times estimated earnings for the year ahead -- about where they should be, given the record commodity prices. "It's hard to imagine commodity prices going up in the next six to eight months," Hackett adds.   Hackett, who is based in London, expects shares of the major players in the metals sector "to drift sideways for the next three to six months . . . until the economic outlook changes." If the global economy slows, as he expects, the sector could take a hit.   As the folks in the mining industry have always known, all that glitters isn't gold. That goes for high-flying stocks, too.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Follow-Up: Foster Wheeler Gets Constructive
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jacqueline Doherty   These are boom times for Foster Wheeler, the big engineering and construction company, which has enjoyed both more business and better margins as global spending on energy projects has taken off. The company's stock (ticker: FWLT) also has been a beneficiary, soaring almost 700%, to a recent a 107, from the 13.43 at which it stood when we first wrote about the company's turnaround ("Survivor," Jan. 31, 2005). The shares aren't particularly expensive, however, because Foster's earnings also have skyrocketed. Earnings are expected to rise to $5.46 a share this year, almost double last year's $2.78. Analysts forecast continued earnings growth in 2008, to $5.95.   The shares are changing hands at just 18 times next year's estimates, roughly even with the broad market's price-earnings multiple and below the 22 times earnings sported by peers Fluor (FLR) and Jacobs Engineering Group (JEC). Foster Wheeler's discount typically is attributed to its near-death experience in 2004, when too much debt and cost overruns resulted in a major restructuring.   With corporate headquarters in Hamilton, Bermuda, and operating headquarters in Clinton, N.J., Foster Wheeler remains confident it's business still has room to run, based on the volume of projects still in the conceptual stage.   If the preliminary work "proceeds to project, it suggests that this market is with us for at least five more years," says an optimistic Ray Milchovich, the company's CEO.   Vance Brown, a principal at Grisanti, Brown & Partners, a New York money manager, sees Foster earning an above-consensus $7 a share in 2008. Giving the stock a 20 multiple on those earnings, he arrives at a target price of $140.   A large chunk of the company's business comes from building refineries and oil and gas facilities. So one risk is a sharp drop in oil prices, now about $68 a barrel, could scuttle projects. Milchovich seems unfazed: "Our view is that these projects all proceed at $45 oil or maybe even less than that," he says.   Investors often overlook another Foster Wheeler business: supplying boilers and other equipment to power providers like utilities. This business, accounting for about 23% of cash flow, looks to be picking up as the world's power needs expand. The could give the company -- and its stock -- an even bigger surge.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Cinven Set To Win BUPA Hospitals Auction -Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Private equity firm Cinven (CVN.YY) is set to win the GBP1.5 billion contest for the U.K. private hospitals of health care provider BUPA, The Times of London reported Saturday, quoting unnamed people familiar with the situation.   The newspaper said that Cinven and CVC (CVC.YY) were the final bidders on the shortlist but CVC was told last night that it was out of the race.   According to the Times, the sources said Cinven was in the final stages of contract negotiations Friday night and that an announcement could come as soon as this weekend, although the sources cautioned that the deal could yet fall apart.   It also needs the approval of the Department of Health, the newspaper said.   BUPA put the 26 U.K. hospitals up for sale in April and the auction attracted interest from a string of private equity bidders, drawn by the value of the property portfolio, strong cash-flows and an ability to sell services to the NHS.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 08:21 ET (12:21 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
