Headline: Barron's(6/18) Profile: Left On The Dock
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By J.R. Brandstrader   Dave Herman is a man of leisure. He spends his time visiting the grandkids in St. Louis, playing golf three or four times a week and traveling to exotic places like the Galapagos. He owes his prosperity to mutual-fund investing, which he's been doing since 1982, usually with success.   "I got hurt in 1987, but I left it all in and eventually made it all back," says the 64-year-old part-time personal trainer, who is retired from the New York City Board of Education. Thecrash of 2000-2002, which was triggered by the bursting of the tech bubble and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, was a different story. "We took a hit just like everybody else," he confesses. "We didn't clear our positions fast enough. We had heard the market was frothy the year before, but it was greed versus fear, and we were piling up money."     These days, Herman keeps a sharper eye on his investments, tracking them via Yahoo! Finance, one of a growing number of sites offering free tools that make it easy to produce instant readings on how your portfolio has done over any period. "I find them very easy to use," he observes. "You can track [a fund] on a daily basis, a yearly basis against its peers and how much is being made. If the fund goes ex-dividend, you can edit the portfolio to add those shares in."   New tools to follow how the investor, rather than the fund, performs are creating a sea-change in mutual-fund investing. The industry generates reams of disclosure documents every year, but until recently most investors had little idea of how they were really doing. The difference between the typical individual's return and the return a fund reports can be startling.   If you deposited $10,000 at the beginning of a one-, three-, five- or 10-year period and just held it -- never depositing more and never withdrawing -- your return would match the marquee total. Few investors, however, enter on the first trading day of a year and then sit tight, neither buying nor selling, for precisely the same periods that funds focus on in prospectuses and ads. And the reality is that a mutual-fund investor's real returns depend greatly on when he sells or buys shares and the amounts involved in the transactions.   But most funds don't make it easy for their shareholders to tell precisely how well or poorly they've done over any given period.     "I have been complaining about this for a decade," said John Bogle, who founded Vanguard, the big mutual-fund company, and now runs Bogle Financial Markets Research Center in Valley Forge, Pa.   Examples of the difference between published returns and what an investor actually gets are plentiful. To cite just two: Calamos Growth A Mid-Cap Growth (ticker: CVGRX) gets five stars from Morningstar for its 10-year return of 18.75%, but the average investor's return was 9.76% in that stretch -- a gap of 8.99 percentage points. Legg Mason Partners Aggressive Growth A (SHRAX), which has four stars from Morningstar, posted a 14.33% average annual return over 10 years (ended March 31) -- 6.50 percentage points better than the 7.83% the typical investor received.   In an e-mail, John P. Calamos Sr., the head of the Calamos fund group, concedes that the calculation is interesting but writes that it "does not reflect the true investor experience but rather a weighted average of what Morningstar perceives to be an experience. Our long-term investors have participated in tremendous performance of the fund despite what this calculation may say." A Legg Mason spokesperson declined to comment.   And the return gap isn't confined to actively managed funds. Vanguard Growth Index (VIGRX) has returned 6.29% over 10 years (ended May 31), while the average investor got just 1.81%, for a 4.48 percentage-point difference.   One thing that hurts investors in such funds is a propensity to pour money into them when the market is rising and thus their share prices are climbing, too, and a reluctance to add money when the market is going south and share prices are on the downswing. Thus, they let opportunities to make big gains steam away, but are on board when their investment ship is about to founder. They buy high and sell low.   In great part, this accounts for a dismal statistic: "The average equity investors' annualized return between 1986 and 2005 was 3.9%, while the Standard & Poor's return was 11.9%," says Lewis Harvey of Boston-based investment-research firm Dalbar.   In short (to borrow from the ancient Roman historian Sallust), investors are, to a large extent, the architects of their own fortunes. Even if the world's greatest stock selector is at the helm of a fund, his work can be futile if his shareholders get in -- or leave -- at the wrong time.   One particularly perilous period: the end of a quarter, when some portfolio chiefs engage in "window dressing," recasting their holdings to make it look as if they contain many of the stocks that have gained the most over the preceding three months.   "Managers don't want to be caught with a dog in the portfolio during their quarterly reporting, so they swap an underperformer for a top performer that makes you look good to your clients," says Jonathan D. Pond, author of You Can Do It: The Boomer's Guide to a Great Retirement.   The mutual-fund industry hasn't been eager to broadcast the discrepancy between reported returns and those that the typical investor gets. It wasn't until last October that Morningstar introduced its Investor Return reading: a dollar-weighted gauge, rather than total return, which is time-weighted.   "We had actually been running the data on a one-off basis for a number of years where we had been looking at cash flows in and out of funds, and we thought it would be a real valuable addition to the investor tool kit to roll it out for all of the funds," says Christine Benz, director of mutual-fund analysis at the Chicago-based investment-research outfit.   Don't count on finding the investor return for every fund that Morningstar rates. The company won't calculate it unless it has complete cash-flow data for a given fund.   Craig L. Israelsen, who teaches family finance at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, says that investor return is a good metric because, in his view, accounting for asset flows in the measurement of performance is a crucial issue.   Financial planner Lewis J. Altfest of New York's L.J. Altfest & Co. doesn't think investor return will steal total return's thunder. "It is an additional item that should be looked at, just like risk-adjusted returns," he says, cautioning that "you are preaching all of this complicated stuff to people who need to know basics."   In any case, Altfest believes that the personal rate of return trumps all other metrics. "People don't look at [their investments' showing] relative to a benchmark. They look at their own performance. If you get a new client when the market goes down, you have a 50% chance of losing that client," he said.   If you want to track your own performance, you can try a formula provided by Henry K. "Bud" Hebeler, the author of J.K. Lasser's Your Winning Retirement Plan: Before-tax return % = 100 x (year-end balance minus beginning-of-year balance, minus the sum of annual deposits plus the sum of annual withdrawals) divided by (beginning-of-year balance plus 1/2 x the sum of annual deposits minus 1/2 x the sum of annual withdrawals).   Got that? If this seems too time-consuming, you can track your investments through free interactive charts provided by Google Finance, Yahoo! Finance and Morningstar. "In our portfolio-manager tool, you can see your individual return on a given fund, based on the timing of your purchases and sales in a tab called 'My Performance,'" says Morningstar's Benz.   Unfortunately, some people don't pay close attention to their personal rate of return, but rather focus on whether the bottom line is growing or shrinking.   What's a lazy investor to do? "Buy good funds in moderate proportion and hang on to them," says Pond, who manages about $100 million. "Over time, there shouldn't be a big gap between stated performance and your dollar-weighted return."   You also can invest in mutual funds with companies that provide personal investment returns on statements. Among them, according to Dalbar, are Allianz Global Investors, American Century Investments, BlackRock, Delaware Investments, Oppenheimer & Co., and Pimco. In addition, some fund groups, like T. Rowe Price, track the average price clients pay for funds -- an important tool for calculating returns.   ---   J.R. Brandstrader teaches journalism at Columbia University in New York.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:02 ET (04:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     A.C. Moore Arts & Crafts   -- ACMR-NNM     Hold   -- Price 21.72 onJune 13   by Wedbush Morgan     The recent scrapbooking reset has been completed and is receiving good customer response . . . company is testing a new digital-scrapbooking area. Market cap: $440 million. Near-term potential negatives include continued softness in yarn . . . [sales, general and administrative costs], cannibalization from backfilling existing markets, and investment costs to implement strategic initiatives. Our 21 target assumes ACMR should trade at 1 time our projected long-term earnings-growth-rate of 20%, or 20 times our 2008 earnings per share estimate of $1.03 . . . based upon its longer-term strong organic growth potential in the profitable arts-and-crafts industry.     Anadarko Petroleum   -- APC-NYSE     Buy/Aggressive   -- Price 49.65 on June 12   by A.G. Edwards     We recently met with Anadarko's Rockies VP, Jim Kleckner, and a number of [other] personnel, focusing on the Greater Natural Buttes/Uinta Basin, Wattenberg/DJ Basin, Powder River Basin/Wyoming coal-bed methane areas and Rockies transportation and pricing. . . . Based on the successful restructuring (asset sales and debt reduction) of APC, multiple operational and financial catalysts, and a still-depressed asset valuation, we are raising our price objective. . . . APC is currently trading at 6.1 times 2007 estimated EV-Ebitda [enterprise value/earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization], 5.5 times 2008E, or roughly a 4% premium to the group, but at only 100% of year-end '07 projected net asset value of $50.28, or 30% below the peer group average. In addition, APC's YE07 proved reserves are trading at . . . a 26% discount to the group. Our revised price objective of $58 [raised from 52] is based on reaching 6.7 times 2007 EV/Ebitda and 115% of NAV, well within historical ranges of 4.5 to 7.5 times and 80% to 150%.     Carlisle Companies   -- CSL-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 43.30 on June 11   by R.W. Baird     Announced departure of current CEO, [which] while surprising, was part of orderly internal transition process. . . . CSL maintains relatively stronger pricing power than other diversified industrials (particularly in roofing). Pricing actions have essentially offset higher materials costs. Management goal of 10% operating margin in primary businesses appears achievable . . . Despite ongoing capital-expansion initiatives, we expect FCF [free cash flow] to expand in '07, providing support for increased acquisition activity and/or financial de-leveraging. A new tire and wheel facility in China should bring $60 million of outsourced product back in-house, [and] 50 new tire [types] are in development at that plant, which should benefit '08 sales . . . Our 53 target is based on a 15 times multiple applied to our 2008 EPS estimate, the average forward P/E [price/earnings ratio] accorded the shares since 1995.     Coley Pharmaceutical Group   -- COLY-NNM     Buy   -- Price 8.16 on June 12   by Merriman Curhan  Ford & Co.     COLY announced the acquisition of clinical and late preclinical-stage compounds from 3M Pharmaceuticals [recently]. Drivers that we believe can provide potential upside for investors in the next year include data from Pfizer's two Phase III clinical trials of PF-3512676 for non-small cell lung cancer, an increased clinical commitment by Pfizer for Coley's compound (PF-3512676) in new cancer indications, and advancement of preclinical drug compounds. . . . Reiterate Buy. In our view, Coley should provide additional upside for investors because of a strong partnered late-stage clinical oncology program, a strengthened pipeline, and potential revenue generation. Data from Pfizer's non-small-cell lung cancer Phase III clinical trials can be expected in late 2007 or early 2008. Market cap: $218 million. Risks: In the biotechnology space, there is always a risk that other companies or universities may have filed or been granted patents [for] technologies similar to [those] used by Coley. Note: there have been patent disputes between Coley and Dynavax.     Fuelcell Energy   -- FCEL-NNM     Buy   -- Price 7.34 on June 13   by Lazard Capital Markets     We recently hosted a site visit with FCEL management at the Sheraton Hotel & Towers in New York, where one of the company's Direct Fuel Cell units is installed. The DFC unit has been in operation two-plus years and provides about 10% of the hotel's electricity needs . . . the unit's waste-heat is used for the hotel's hot-water requirements. We are reaffirming our thesis that the company is in a position to receive the largest order in its history, related to Connecticut's Project 100 . . . Bookings prospects in other key markets also remain strong and the company recently received . . . orders in South Korea.   Management . . . expects to achieve an additional 20%-to-25% cost reduction through volume benefits. As with any company in the early states of commercialization, primary risks include balancing cash burn while establishing key strategic markets. Our 12-month price target of 11 reflects a 30 times multiple on two potential revenue and earnings scenarios, 90 cents to $1.20 over the next five to seven years, discounted back five years at 25%, given the risk associated with early-stage commercial companies.     Interactive Brokers Group   -- IBKR-NNM     Buy   -- Price 28.70 on June 13   by Sandler O'Neill & Partners     With 15.9% market share of exchange-listed equity-options volume traded worldwide last year, we believe IBKR is well-positioned to take advantage of the strong secular growth in option volumes. From 2001-'06, the compound annual growth rate from global options was 18%, while U.S. options grew 20.9%, and exchange-traded derivatives grew 34%. This growth has accelerated over the past two years. Penny-pricing, while a risk, is also a potential positive for volume. In January, the Securities and Exchange Commission began a pilot program to trade options on 13 securities in reduced increments. Initial results from the pilot appear to show that volume increases outweigh declines in profitability for market makers. But the SEC has not [yet] decided whether to extend or expand the pilot. While [an] expanded pilot might have negative implications for IBKR's trading profitability, tighter spreads might also lead to volume growth that offsets any effect on trading gains . . . We expect IBKR to earn $1.32 per share in 2007 and $1.58 in 2008. Our $32 price target is based on a 20 times multiple of our 2008 EPS projection. We justify this multiple based on our projection for 19.7% earnings growth in 2008 and a P/E to growth ratio of 1 time.     McAfee   -- MFE-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 35.12 on June 13   by Pacific Crest     At [recent] analyst day in New York City, CEO Dave DeWalt articulated a bullish plan targeting new opportunities and further operational efficiencies. Overall, it reinforced our thesis that McAfee will continue to gain market share in its consumer and corporate businesses as well as improve operating margin. We believe that DeWalt and new senior level executives are working to streamline McAfee and drive further operational efficiencies in its various business segments. In our view, this should lead to expansion of operating margin in 2008 beyond our 25.8% forecast. The company said it will likely have its internal options review completed . . . by the end of June. While full financials are not likely to be filed until late Q3 . . . our fundamental outlook is unchanged. Our price target of $43 is based on 23 times our 2008 EPS estimate of $1.85. Market and macroeconomic condition could interfere with this price target, [yet] . . . McAfee is benefiting from the sector's ongoing strength. The company has eliminated its underperforming and nonstrategic Sniffer, Magic and NAI Labs business units and is focusing on its core competency.     NeurogesX   --NGSX-NNM     Buy   -- Price 7.95 on June 12   by Pacific Growth Equities     NeurogesX's topical capsaicin patch and follow-on, high-dose capsaicin liquid formulation have the potential, in our opinion, to become the standard of care for the treatment of [several types of pain, such as pain from post-herpetic neuralgia, HIV digital-sensory neuropathy and diabetic neuropathy] . . . While there are no publicly disclosed plans at this time for studies in these settings, we do not believe these opportunities should be ignored when considering NGSX . . . we estimate NGSX has sufficient cash to late 2008 (without European partnership) and into mid-'09 . . . the emerging role of topical treatments in the very large osteoarthritis and back-pain markets could tip the economics in favor of a global transaction. We project NGSX should achieve product sales in the U.S. in 2012 of $287 million and royalties from European sales of $14 million. Based upon 18 times and 7 times multiples of our fiscal-year $14 million and $287 million royalty and sales estimates or 30 times our FY12 $6.28/share EPS estimate, and 30% discount rate, we put the potential fair value of NGSX at approximately 49 to 52 per share.     RBC Bearings   -- ROLL-NNM     Outperform   -- Price 39.91 on June 13   by Barrington Research     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Speaking Of Dividends: Dow Duo Vote Raises
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   Dividends are taking off again at United Technologies.   Wednesday, the $48 billion aerospace and building-services conglomerate boosted its quarterly common payout 21%, to 32 cents a share from 26.5 cents. Holders of record Aug. 17 are scheduled to receive the enhanced payout Sept. 10. The ex-dividend date is Aug. 15. At a 52-week high Friday above 72, the stock yields 1.78%.   Hartford, Conn.-based United Technologies (ticker: UTX) has nearly tripled its dividend in the past six years, and this is the 14th consecutive year in which it has hiked it. "The board's action reflects consistently strong cash flow and affirms our confidence in sustained earnings growth," said Chief Executive George David.   Dividends have been paid without interruption since 1936. The company repurchased $2.07 billion worth of its common in 2006 and has plenty of room left in the current authorization to pick up more.   United Tech, whose corporate roots stretch back to 1853, when Elisha Graves Otis opened his elevator factory, is best known for its Otis elevators (No. 1 in the world), Carrier heating and air-conditioning systems (ditto), Pratt & Whitney jet engines and Sikorsky helicopters. Its engines power better than 50% of the world's commercial airliners, and its systems can be found on over 90% of the globe's aircraft.   First-quarter net rose 7% from the level a year earlier, to $819 million, or 82 cents a share, on a 16% gain in revenue, to $12.28 billion. United Tech expects to post full-year per-share net of $4.05 and $4.20 a share, versus 2006's $3.71. Volume is likely to rise 6.7%, to more than $51 billion.   The company says it's positioned to capitalize on expected strong growth in Asia. "We have some of the best emerging-market exposure of any company in the world," declared David. In addition, as a leading maker of fuel cells, United Tech is looking for ways to recapture energy lost during manufacturing and other operations.     Another of the world's industrial goliaths, Dow component Caterpillar (CAT), sweetened its common dividend Wednesday and, like United Tech, for the 14th year in a row. The new quarterly will be 36 cents a share, up 20% from 30 cents. It's payable Aug. 20 to investors on the books July 20. The stock goes ex-dividend July 18. This is the third straight year in which the Peoria, Ill., company has boosted its disbursement by at least 20%. Yield: 1.78%.   CEO James W. Owens credits the move to "directors' continued confidence in Caterpillar's long-term outlook." Dividends have been ongoing since Cat's formation in 1925, via the merger of a pair of companies dating back to 1890.   The Dow industrials Wednesday posted their biggest one-day gain for 2007, and Cat was one of the leaders of the charge, climbing 2.4% and setting a 52-week high of 79.97. Friday it surged above 81.   The world's No. 1 maker of earth-moving machinery and a leading supplier of agricultural equipment, Cat also is a big maker of truck engines and power generators. The company is projecting 2007 earnings of $5.30 to $5.80 a share on $42 billion to $44 billion in sales-for its fourth consecutive record year. By 2010, Cat expects to be earning $8 to $10 a share on volume of $45 billion to $60 billion. Cat has ample cash flow to continue substantial stock buybacks.     Elsewhere in last week's dividend news, laid-back-clothing producer American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) dressed up its dividend 33%, to 10 cents a share from 7.5 cents. Payouts were initiated in September 2004, and this is the fourth boost, along with two stock splits. A stock-buyback program is in place . . . Giant discount retailer Target (TGT) raised its quarterly two cents, to 14 cents a share, and sweetened its buyback authorization by $3 billion, to $8 billion. Target has more than three decades of dividend growth to its credit . . . The nation's third-largest auto insurer, Progressive (PGR), will use about $3 billion in excess capital to pay a special dividend of $2 a share and to repurchase up to 100 million of its shares over the next two years.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Barron's Roundtable: Room To Run
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lauren R. Rubin   Dow 14,000, or bust.   Suddenly either alternative seems possible for stocks, as the outlook for interest rates turns murky. The Dow industrials and the Standard & Poor's 500 could race to new highs as corporate profits keep climbing -- or fall amid signs that the greatest party ever is ending for bonds.   With some notable exceptions, the members of the Barron's Roundtable still take the positive view and expect stocks to log modest gains in 2007, despite a correction, or even two. That's the story these celebrated investors told when we sat them down for their annual grilling Jan. 8, and they're sticking with it: The U.S. economy will grow by about 2% for the year; inflation will stay benign; profits will increase by 6% to 8%, and don't you just love natural-resources shares?   To be sure, our experts have a few fears: that the housing market's woes could worsen, crippling the consumer, and that there's a ticking bomb somewhere in that mountain of leverage built by the buyout kings. But they predict the fuse won't light -- that is, interest rates and their proxy, bond yields, won't head heavenward -- any time soon. In the pages that follow they explain why, and share their investment picks for the rest of what has become a most interesting year.     BILL GROSS     Barron's: You surely know how to make news, Bill, by turning bearish on bonds. What happened?   Gross: I raised my forecast for 10-year Treasury yields from a range of 4% to 5.5% to a range of 4% to 6.5%. It now appears the global economy isn't going to slow.To be fair, Pimco and I were impressed by global growth in the past few years, but were also suspicious that something would cause it to slow -- a declining dollar or a change in the current-account deficit or an implosion related to financial leverage. Now some of those fears have been pushed to the background. It looks like China is going to keep growing, and India, too, and that will influence the rest of the world. It's a glass half-full outlook, as opposed to a glass half-empty.     Q: Tell us, how does it feel?   A: It doesn't feel good. Bond guys are supposed to take the half-empty view. Our charge is like that of the New York Police Department: Preserve and protect. And our positions still suggest there will be a slowdown in the U.S., due to housing. But strong global growth does have repercussions in terms of the building blocks of bond prices -- namely, inflation. A few years from now, labor costs probably will move from having a deflationary to a reflationary impact, at the margin. Most of the cheap labor will be used up, and China's export prices will be revalued higher. Instead of a 2% inflation rate, we might be looking at 2.5% headed toward 3% toward the end of a five-year period.   The bond market sees some near-term cyclical strengthening in a number of areas. Bernanke [Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke] and the Fed have spoken to the fact that as we move toward the end of 2007, the economy will be moving back toward its growth potential. That's Fed-code for 2%, plus or minus, in the U.S. economy's real growth rate.     Q: But what about the weak housing market, to which you just referred?   A: We got the housing problem right, and it will continue to be a problem. It just hasn't rubbed off on the rest of the economy in the way we thought, in terms of employment or consumer confidence. It could have a weakening effect on consumers for the rest of the year, but other, more positive things are in place. Still, we are watching housing. We are watching trends in some of the more esoteric leveraged vehicles out there, and in the private-equity market.     Q: How have you changed your portfolio to reflect your altered world view?   A: We're positioned a little differently than we were in the past month or two. Our bond maturities and durations have moved a little closer to the Lehman Aggregate Index. More important, we're keeping our concentrations toward the front end of the yield curve, certainly in the U.S. That's because of the Fed, which is taking a wait-and-see attitude, and another complicating factor: the trend toward the development of sovereign wealth funds [large pools of money that sovereign nations are investing in stocks, commodities and assets other than government bonds]. This is something you can't model and for which there is little history. The best example, to date, is China's planned $3 billion investment in the Blackstone Group.     Q: That's $3 billion that could have been invested in Treasury bonds.   A: If money at the margin begins to move away from Treasuries into something else, then, yes, bonds are going to be affected. It helps to explain why bond yields never rose much as the Fed was raising rates since early 2004. As a money manager you want to be out front of the train. If they are not going to be buying Treasuries, maybe we should be unloading some of ours before they unload some of theirs. I am not suggesting China will be dumping Treasuries, but that at the margin Treasuries might not be bought. The Treasuries that won't be bought are the five-years, the 10-years and the 30-years -- the things they own. China and its compatriots own about 65% or 70% of these bonds. The front end of the yield curve is controlled by the Fed as opposed to the Chinese. It is not totally safe, as the Fed raises and lowers rates. But it is safer to analyze what the Fed might do than whether and what the Chinese might buy. Especially if sovereign wealth funds get going, the front end of the curve is the safe place to be.   On the other hand, you want to stay away from risky types of credits, as spreads are compressed. The typical high-yield index yields about 7% these days, versus the 5.2% yield on 10-year Treasuries.   That's awfully close for comfort.   Exactly. You could get 7% instead of 5% for the next six months, but what happens when there's a problem? Smart investors tend to anticipate these things and sell high-yield bonds, which in and of itself can beget more selling. Corporate bonds for the most part, and high-yields, and certainly subprime debt are moving into a vulnerable period, unless the economy really snaps back to its good old healthy self. We don't see that happening.   We do like some emerging-market debt, despite the attendant risks. Many of these countries in effect are less risky than the U.S. China is not an emerging market; it has a trillion dollars of reserves. The U.S. has only $50 billion, or 20 times less, in the bank. Brazil has $120 billion of reserves and offers interest rates in the 9%-10% category, well above high-yield bonds. It's not like the old days, when countries like Argentina defaulted on their debt.     Q: How about some specific recommendations?   A: In January, I recommended the iShares MSCI EAFE Index [ticker: EFA], an exchange-traded fund, which has done well in recent years. It represents stocks outside the U.S., in Europe, Asia, Australia and New Zealand. It is a play on lower valuations in the rest of the world, and stronger growth. And it benefits by being denominated in foreign currencies. The dollar is weak and getting weaker as we move through 2007. The Pimco Floating Rate Strategy Fund [PFN] offers another good opportunity. It yields 8.9%. It is a floating-rate bank-loan fund, and therefore a defensive holding if rates move higher. It provides first-lien protection if a company falters.   Thank you, Bill.   MARIO GABELLI   Q: How does the second half look to you, Mario?   Gabelli: We thought the economy would be sluggish in the first half because of inventory corrections in housing and the automotive market. Things have unfolded more or less along those lines, with the rest of the world looking stronger than the U.S. By the second half of the year the inventory correction in automotive will be out of the way. The housing market will remain sluggish, but the inventory correction in that market will be gone in 2008. In the meantime, exports, nonresidential construction, capital expenditures, wages and the wealth effect provide ballast. At the other end of the economy, consumers will suffer from higher gasoline prices and declining home values. Bottom line, the economy muddles through and starts looking brighter in '08. Short-term interest rates will stay at 5%; long-term rates will go up to 5.5%. The dollar will be weaker, particularly relative to the Japanese yen. Put all that in the mix, add a stock-market correction of 10% to 15% at some point, and the market will be up at most 5% for the year. I'm not negative. I just think '08 will be a lot better.     Q: At least the deal market is hopping, something you predicted for years.   A: I predicted lovemaking by the corporate world. Now the private-equity world has jumped in. The key question people in every corporate boardroom are asking is: Why do we need to protect our triple-A debt rating if the private-equity guys can buy us out and take on eight times our debt? Should we engage in financial engineering, taking on more debt to buy back shares? But the concept of greater leverage hasn't been stress-tested yet. The next time there is an economic slowdown and the banks don't lend as they did, that's when you'll need a healthy balance sheet. Right now boards aren't looking at stress-testing. They are looking at things like debt covenants and "covenant lites."     Q: Explain, please.   A: Covenants are those elements in a loan indenture that say you need to have some multiple of cash flow relative to interest expense, so much debt to equity, so much interest expense and so on. Covenant lites don't have these restrictions. They allow you to go through a period of economic distress and not have an embarrassing moment.   On the deal front, corporate buyers are rampant. But the headline grabbers are the private-equity guys, who account for only about a quarter of the deals. We are no longer at the dawn of the fourth major takeover boom since the 1950s. But we are certainly not at the sunset. We are probably just starting the mid-afternoon.     Q: When does the stress-testing come?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Barron's Roundtable: Room To Run -7-
Story: Endo's core franchise is pain management, and its main product is Lidoderm, the only topical analgesic patch indicated to treat the pain of post-herpetic neuralgia. This product generated $567 million in sales in 2006 and has seen scripts [prescriptions] continue to grow at about 20% this year. Some are concerned about a potential generic threat to Lidoderm, but as of today, no one has filed and we and the company are confident in Endo's patent position.     Q: When do its patents expire?   A: The patent on Lidoderm has been extended through 2015. It is difficult to develop a generic of this type. Endo has recently launched its Opana franchise, for treatment of moderate to severe pain with the use of an opioid. After a slow initial launch, scripts are starting to accelerate rapidly, consistent with the company's increased marketing effort. Over time, Opana will represent an attractive asset.   Endo also has an interesting pipeline. It includes several late-stage opportunities, such as a topical ketoprofen patch for the treatment of acute pain associated with soft-tissue injuries, and Rapinyl, a fast-dissolving fentanyl tablet for breakthrough cancer pain. Both are currently in Phase III testing and are expected to be launched in 2009. Other products in development include EN 3285, a topical oral-rinse formulation for oral mucositis, currently in Phase II, and Frova, a long-acting triptan for which Endo is seeking menstrual-migraine-prevention indication, which could enhance the size of its current franchise. The FDA must say "Yeah" or "Nay" on this by Aug. 19. Endo has a strong and seasoned management team, including President and CEO Peter Lankau; Chief Scientific Officer David Lee and CFO Charlie Rowland.     Q: Where is the stock priced?   A: It trades for 34. By year end the company will have about a billion dollars, or $7.50 a share, in cash, and no debt. With this cash position, as well as continued strong cash flows, Endo is looking to make strategic investments, which may include acquisitions. We estimate Endo could earn about $2.40 a share in 2008. Excluding cash, that implies the stock is trading for about 11 times 2008 earnings, a significant discount to other specialty-pharmaceutical companies that don't have such pipeline assets or growth prospects.     Q: Are you betting the company will be bought out?   A: It is not part of the investment case, as it wasn't with Kos. My second pick has a market capitalization of only $300 million. It is relatively illiquid. Uluru [ULUR] is an early-stage company with an exciting technology and tremendous opportunities in large market applications. It is developing a portfolio of products using two innovative delivery technologies. The first is OraDisc, a transmucosal-delivery system, which has been approved by the FDA. The second involves hydrogel nanoparticle aggregate technology. The company already has three FDA-approved products and is in clinical trials on several product applications.     Q: How do these technologies work?   A: OraDisc can deliver drugs systemically across the mucosal surface or into the oral cavity. The device, which is effectively a small oral patch, can be tailored to various erosion rates to deliver therapeutics over different time intervals. This technology has numerous potential applications including oral, dental, systemic drug delivery and veterinary, and the company has signed several licensing arrangements with industry partners.     Q: What are the benefits of the hydrogel technology?   A: Uluru's hydrogel nanoparticle aggregate technology has been used to form a bio-material of varying strength and elasticity that has extensive applications in a range of potential uses. The most interesting include an alternative breast implant, projected to be a billion-dollar business; dermal fillers, another billion-dollar market, and advanced wound dressings, part of a $15 billion market. You have this small, white nanoparticle powder in an envelope, and let's say you're wounded in Iraq. Open the package, put the powder on your wound and it turns into a bandage, with antiseptics and antibiotics incorporated in it.   Uluru has an outstanding management team, lead by President and CEO Kerry Gray, and is in discussions with large numbers of industry players about developing these applications and bringing them to market. It reported positive cash flow in the first quarter and has a low expense structure, but it is too early to track the company on a quarterly earnings basis. It is an investment with a three-to-five-year horizon, which from its current price of about 5 a share could be a five-to-10-bagger.     Q: Nice. How did you happen upon Uluru?   A: It was brought to me by a friend in the business for 30 years. The company came to see us when the stock was about a dollar. It had a total enterprise value of $50 million. They did a $38 million financing, and we bought $10 million worth. We now own a little less than 20% of the company.     Thanks, Oscar.     ABBY JOSEPH COHEN     Q: You recently raised your 2007 earnings estimate for the S&P 500, as well as your year-end price target. Why?   A: Cohen: When we revised our estimate of operating earnings to $93 from $92, we also adjusted our year-end S&P price target modestly, to 1600 from 1550. First-quarter earnings came in stronger than we had expected, which gave us a higher baseline. More important, 2008 looks to be another year in which inflation is under control and economic growth continues. Toward the end of 2007, investors should be willing to pay for '08 results. That was our main motivation for 1600; the comparable number on the Dow Jones Industrial Average is 14,000. If our numbers are right, total returns this year, including dividends, will be about 15%.     Q: You're more optimistic than most.   A: Our forecast is a reflection of several things. The market began the year at attractive valuation levels, whether you look at multiples of earnings or sales, or comparable metrics. This is not a market that looks overdone. Our valuations are based on dividend-discount and discounted-cash-flow models. We use eight different mathematical assumptions that we think are reasonable. We are not reaching for the stars, and in some cases we try to be overly conservative. For example, even though intermediate and long-term interest rates have gone up in the past few weeks, they are still below the numbers built into our models. Also, we plug in earnings-growth estimates that are well below historical trends.   Many people who were concerned about 2007 pointed out properly that earnings growth would be slowing. Therefore, they couldn't see how stocks would go much higher. Our position has been different; we thought this might be a long-lasting economic expansion, in which case you could have a period of moderate growth and share prices still could rise. Historically inventory corrections bring U.S. economic cycles to an end, but inventories are under control. The expansion of the late 1990s was brought to an end through too much enthusiasm for business investment. That is not happening now. Globally, most established economies are experiencing moderate growth, and core inflation doesn't seem to be rising rapidly.     Q: Do you see any signs that the stock market is overheating?   A: In the public markets, no. We feel pretty comfortable with the market trading at 15-16 times earnings. The market doesn't look overheated on a price-to-sales basis, either. However, we expressed concerns about bonds prior to the recent selloff, especially lower-grade securities. We expressed concern about the narrow yield gap between high-quality bonds and lower-quality bonds, and now investors seem to have a lessened tolerance for that sort of risk. When volatility began to rise, as we expected, investors began to pay more attention to risks endemic to lower-quality bonds and lower-quality stocks.     Q: What could trip up this market?   A: There are long-term clouds, not near-term. These include things like U.S fiscal policy, the budget deficit, the aging of the baby boomers, who start to collect transfer payments and stop paying income taxes at very high rates. The long-term health of state and local governments also could prove problematic. There are liabilities associated with pensions, retiree health care and so on. But the real concern should be for other countries, whose populations are aging faster than ours. The U.S. benefits from immigration, and we have a higher birth rate than many countries. Europe, Japan and China all are aging faster.   In the near-to-intermediate term, the economy will grow at a 2.5%-3% rate. Core inflation will drift upward. The Fed will not undertake ugly policies any time soon. We just don't see the fundamentals disrupting the market. Geopolitical events are in another category, but we don't know how to forecast them. One thing we see is sector rotation. Incremental economic growth is coming from the more cyclical components of the U.S. economy: business investments, capital spending, exports. We still think this is a long cycle in energy. We are going to see renewed investment by energy companies. From the standpoint of S&P 500 earnings, energy companies are still doing extremely well. But their rate of profit growth has decelerated, which is one reason earnings growth overall is not as robust this year.     Q: Which energy companies do you like?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Follow-Up: Carlos Ghosn's Comeback: Will It Work?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jay Palmer   Ghosn still is riding the trends -- only now they are headed down. In May, Renault's new-car sales plummeted nearly 10% in France, its home market.   That was only the latest bad news to hit Ghosn, who after becoming chief operating officer of Nissan in 1999 led the Japanese company from a record loss to six consecutive years of record profits.   Earlier this year, Nissan, 40% owned by Renault, missed its earnings and sales targets for the first time under Ghosn, prompting the company to cut jobs and close production lines. It also admitted that its public commitment to boost worldwide auto sales to 4.2 million vehicles by 2009 -- an 18% increase over the '05 sales number -- was now impossible. Ghosn decided he'd been doing too much and gave up direct oversight of Nissan's North American operations. "One man can't humanly do what he was trying to do," says Pierre Nebout, who manages about 4 billion euros ($5 billion) in French and European stocks at Edmond de Rothschild Asset Management in Paris. "Now I believe the worst is over. Ghosn has a very good comeback strategy and it is on track."   But Renault's stock (RND.France), up almost 30% just since March, may have gotten ahead of the turnaround, Nebout suggests. Nissan's Amercian depositary receipts (NSANY) are down 9% since the start of the year, to 21.80, and could easily fall further if there are more missteps.   If there was one big flaw in Ghosn's latest three-year plan, it was a lack of new models at both Nissan and Renault in 2005 and 2006, when rivals such as Toyota and Honda were launching improved cars.   Ghosn means to change that. In North America, Nissan has launched the subcompact Versa and the Infinity G35 luxury sedan. In Japan, it recently introduced the Clipper Rio, a new mini wagon. After the launches of the second-generation Twingo and the budget Dacia Logan early this year, the hope in Europe is to get Renault sales moving higher again with the make-or-break Renault Laguna, a performance car that goes on sale in October.   Given Ghosn's track record, there's good reason to bet he'll come from behind in this race. Trouble is, too many investors already are waving the checkered flag at the finish line.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Pearson Decision On Les Echos Sale Expected -FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--U.K. media and publishing firm Pearson (PSON.LN) is expected to decide on a sale of France's leading financial newspaper Les Echos within weeks after receiving interest from several potential bidders, the Financial Times reported Saturday.   The newspaper said a sale could raise an estimated EUR200 million (GBP135m) for Pearson. Pearson publishes the FT   According to the paper, Bernard Arnault, chief executive of the LVMH (12101.FR) luxury goods group, is understood to be among those examining Les Echos, possibly through LVMH or as a private investment.   Other French industrialists including Vincent Bollori and Arnaud Lagardhre have been linked with Les Echos in the past, the FT reported.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 07:27 ET (11:27 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Capitalia, Mediobanca Approve EUR1.24B Loan For Gemina -Paper
Story: MILAN (Dow Jones)--Italian banks Capitalia SpA (CAP.MI) and Mediobanca SpA (MB.MI) Friday approved a EUR1.24 billion loan for Gemina SpA (GEM.MI) to finance its bid to buy out Macquarie Airports' (MAP.AU) stake in Rome's airports operator, Italian daily Il Sole 24 Ore reported Saturday.   Australia's Macquarie Airports agreed Thursday to sell its minority stake in Rome airports operator Aeroporti di Roma, or AdR, to Italian holding company Gemina for EUR1.2 billion to EUR1.3 billion, a person familiar with the matter said.   The move would end months of wrangling between Macquarie and Gemina - which already controls 51% of AdR - over how best to upgrade aging infrastructure at Rome's Fiumicino and Ciampino airports.   Speaking on condition of anonymity, another person familiar with the matter said Gemina's board will meet Sunday to review the situation.   According to Il Sole, Mediobanca and Capitalia will provide Gemina a bridge loan of EUR1.24 billion to pay Macquarie, while later on a capital increase and debts will finance the deal.     Newspaper Web site: www.ilsole24ore.com     -Milan Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 348 7678016     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 09:07 ET (13:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/18) Barron's Online: Blue Nile In Treacherous Waters
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Johanna Bennett   Blue Nile may be the pharaoh of online jewelry merchants, but its high-flying stock could be dethroned.   At their recent price of $58.83, Blue Nile shares (ticker: NILE) had more than doubled since hitting a two-year low last summer, outpacing both the basket of online retail stocks tracked by Thomson Financial and the Standard & Poor's 500.   Fast-growing profits, higher guidance, a well-respected management team and a growing market for online jewelry sales have fueled great expectations.   But Blue Nile's success could attract competition from online rivals with deeper pockets. And since hitting a record high last month, the shares command a premium that leaves little room for disappointment. So, it's no wonder that substantial selling by insiders has raised a few eyebrows (Inside Scoop, May 15).   "If you are going to be disciplined about investing, you can't say 'Let's keep watching it go up, up, up,'" says Brian Bolan, an analyst with Jackson Securities, which downgraded Blue Nile last month to a Sell. "You have to be disciplined and lock in profits, and this is a time to lock in some profits."   Bolan isn't alone in that view.   Last month, American Technology Research initiated coverage with a Sell rating, and Lehman Brothers downgraded the stock to Equal Weight from Overweight.   In addition, ten Blue Nile insiders have sold 662,700 shares worth $32.8 million thus far this year, compared with 255,500 shares sold in all of 2006 by eight insiders, says Ben Silverman, director of research for InsiderScore.com.   "When insiders boost the size of their sales and accelerate the rate of profit-taking, it's a good time for investors to step back and take a look at their own position," says Silverman.   A company spokesman declined to comment.   Founded in 1999 when CEO Mark Vadon purchased the assets and small Website of a Seattle jeweler (he signed a promissory note on the back of a dinner napkin), Blue Nile is a thorn in the side of mom-and-pop retail jewelry stores.   The company's Website hawks diamond rings, sapphire pendants and pearl earrings, as well as watches and sterling silver jewelry. But Blue Nile gets about 90% of its revenue by selling diamond jewelry. Its bread and butter remains nervous grooms buying engagement rings, says John Baird, a company spokesman.     "I was skeptical early on," says Ken Gassman, president of the Jewelry Industry Research Institute. "I didn't think anyone would buy diamond rings online."   Blue Nile operates no stores, is disciplined about spending and keeps little inventory. All this guarantees price tags up to 40% lower than those of a traditional jeweler. Shoppers can custom-build a diamond ring on the Website. And they have 30 days to return merchandise for a full refund.   "They figured out a way to cut out some of the expenses and pass the value on to customers," says Mark Oelschlager, a portfolio manager at Oak Associates. "Word of mouth helped the business, and people flocked to the Website."   Or as Baird puts it: "It's Dell with Tiffany wrapping."   Talk about good timing. Online jewelry sales could more than double by 2010 to $6 billion, stealing 10% of the $60 billion U.S. jewelry market.   But neither Blue Nile nor online jewelry sales are entirely bulletproof.   Wall Street has set the bar high for earnings growth, projecting annual average gains of 21% over the next three to five years. This year, industry analysts expect the company to post profits of 90 cents a share, up 19% from 2006, and they project another 21% hike in 2008.   But after a 20% leap last year, the rate of growth for online jewelry sales is slowing, according to IDEX Research. And a weak housing market could lead some consumers to rethink their spending habits.   Rising diamond and precious-metal costs could put pressure on Blue Nile's gross margins, cautions Tim Boyd, an analyst at American Technology Research. The quarter that ends June 30 historically is a weak one for jewelers. If Blue Nile "reports merely in-line earnings," for that stretch, "the stock could correct as much as 10%," he maintains.   Meanwhile, store-based retailers, such as Kay Jewelers, are ramping up their online commerce efforts. And Blue Nile's success in selling high-end jewelry could attract larger online rivals, including Amazon.com (AMZN). That company already sells jewelry on its flagship Website. An Amazon spokeswoman declined to comment on its jewelry plans.   Like diamonds, Blue Nile's stock isn't cheap. At 63 times projected profits over the next four quarters, the shares trade well above their five-year median of 44 times forward earnings, a 50% premium to the basket of online retail stocks tracked by Thomson Financial.   To be sure, fans of the stock remain dazzled. And they point to the positives:     With Websites in Canada and the United Kingdom, Blue Nile could enter more markets in the next 12 to 18 months. Meanwhile, in the U.S., online jewelry sales continue to grow and take business away from brick-and-mortar vendors. In addition, the company is buying back stock.   But the recent rating downgrades could "keep expectations in check," Oak's Oelschlager warns. And, given the stock's big run, Blue Nile will have to put up better-than-expected quarterly numbers to not falter. Finally, despite speculation that someone will buy the company, a takeout seems unlikely at the current stock price.   So investors hoping to add a little bling to their portfolios would do better to shop elsewhere.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 16, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : National Lampoon Announces Third Quarter Fiscal 2007 Financial Results
Story: LOS ANGELES--(BUSINESS WIRE)--June 16, 2007--   National Lampoon, Inc. (AMEX:NLN), the leading brand in comedy, today released its financial results for the third quarter ended April 30, 2007.     The Company reported revenues of $813,917, compared to $1,537,806 for the third quarter of 2006 along with a net loss of $1,161,000 or ($0.18) per fully diluted share as compared with a net loss of $1,395,000 or ($0.25) per fully diluted share for the third quarter of fiscal 2006. The decrease in revenue was primarily attributable to a pullback from the travel segment of the business, along with a decrease in promotion revenue, partially offset by an increase in advertising revenue, as the Company is now more focused on Internet advertising. The net loss for the third quarter includes non cash costs associated with accrued preferred stock dividends, option grants, and costs related to new Internet and film production initiatives.     "It is very promising to see the growth in our online advertising revenue. Our relationships with Veoh, Joost, YouTube, and AOL Video, as well as our own properties, NationalLampoon.com, Knuckleheadvideo.com, and TogaTV.com, mean not only that our customers continue to believe in our brand and content, but that we now have even stronger platforms for distribution," commented Daniel Laikin, Chief Executive Officer. "Our Internet content strategy continues to flourish with hits such as 'National Lampoon's 72 Virgins,' 'Star Wars, X-Wing Pilots - the Deleted Scene' and our newest property, 'Fat Guy Nation.'"     "I am also excited to welcome the traffic from our newest acquisition, DrunkUniversity.com. We feel this acquisition will be a focal point to our core college age humor market," continued Laikin. "This quarter, we also focused on expanding the breadth of our content by producing motion pictures and publishing books through National Lampoon Press. I look forward to seeing the results as we continue our efforts to expand our film brand, grow our advertiser and user base, and continue to dedicate efforts on building our online platforms and increasing our opportunities."     National Lampoon is in post production of its first motion picture, "National Lampoon's Bag Boy," and recently commenced principal photography on its second feature, "Ratko, the Dictator's Son."     The selected financial data, including the results of operations for the three-month and nine-month periods ended April 30, 2007 compared to 2006, and the financial positions as of April 30, 2007 compared to July 31, 2006, is summarized in the following table:    Selected Financial Data (unaudited)                                      Three Months Ended      (2,086)          (1,506)    Working capital                               (6,783)          (4,080)       About National Lampoon     National Lampoon, Inc. (AMEX:NLN) has been a dominant force in the US comedy world for almost 30 years and is currently active in a broad array of media and entertainment segments, including feature films, television programming, online and interactive entertainment, home video, audio CDs and book publishing. The Company also owns interests in all major National Lampoon properties, including National Lampoon's Animal House, the National Lampoon Vacation series and National Lampoon's Van Wilder. National Lampoon reaches nearly one in four of all 18 to 24 year old college students in America today. The Company has three core operating divisions: Entertainment Division, College Marketing Division, and a distribution arm National Lampoon Networks, providing content traditionally through its College TV network and across new media through multiple in-house digital platforms including NationalLampoon.com, DrunkUniversity.com, TogaTV.com, Knuckleheadvideo.com, the National Lampoon Video Network (which includes channels on AOL, Joost, YouTube and others) and the National Lampoon Humor Network - the most trafficked humor sites on the web - along with multiple other outlets housed on its online comedy website www.nationallampoon.com.
